147386194.review:
Uno de los aspectos más destacados de Out There Somewhere es su ingenioso sistema de portales. Yuri tiene un arma especial que puede disparar portales a superficies específicas del nivel. Estos portales se utilizan tanto para desplazarse por el mundo como para resolver puzles. La habilidad para colocar portales y utilizarlos de manera estratégica es fundamental para superar los obstáculos y enemigos del juego.

El juego ha sido elogiado por su dificultad bien equilibrada y su diseño de niveles ingenioso. Cada nivel presenta desafíos únicos que requieren habilidad, reflexión y un buen uso de los portales para superar. Los controles son simples pero precisos, lo que permite a los jugadores realizar movimientos precisos y rápidos, lo que es esencial para superar los obstáculos del juego.

A pesar de su estilo visual retro, Out There Somewhere ha sido elogiado por su estética encantadora y su música pegajosa que se adapta perfectamente al ambiente del juego. La historia minimalista se presenta de manera efectiva a través de imágenes y eventos del juego, lo que permite a los jugadores sentirse conectados emocionalmente con el personaje de Yuri y su viaje.

Sin embargo, algunas críticas han señalado que el juego puede resultar corto para algunos jugadores experimentados, aunque otros consideran que su duración es adecuada dada su dificultad y estilo de juego.

One is beating the game in 20 minutes (a reasonable player can achieve this in 15), and another is to collect all 11 cores: a hidden in-game collectible. 139783133.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Visually, it's not much to look at. Although the character portrait designs and color choices are nice, the pixel art of the environments and characters is sorta generic
- The music is pretty decent. Again, sorta generic little chiptunes, but still nice

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- Given that it's a short game, the story is a quick run through. In a nutshell, your ship is shot down as you're pursuing the game's villain. After crash landing, you need to find a part to fix your ship as well as some (optional) upgrades to make it stronger
- Not much going on vibe-wise. It's a relatively chill little puzzle platformer

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- The game largely plays as a puzzle platformer with a focus on exploration
- You just run through the environments solving jumping puzzles. Paying close attention to the room layout and small details within each screen may yield additional upgrades for your ship, which make the final boss easier
- I might be back in the future to replay and nab some more achievements. It's a fun, quick game

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- Being such an inexpensive game, it's really hard to get too upset about the slightly generic design and gameplay. It's well worth the price of admission
- Ran perfectly fine on the Steam Deck after switching from Proton Experimental -> 8.02

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]6/10[/b]. It's a competently-made puzzle platformer at an extremely good value. If you're craving a platformer but don't have much time, this is an easy game to recommend

125212567.review:
Some indie games just need a good idea to justify their reason for existing, and Out There Somewhere’s teleport gun serves that purpose. During its short play time, the game builds on its core mechanics enough to feel satisfying just before it wears out its welcome. This makes it worthwhile at its budget price-point as a fun proof-of-concept and makes it a fun “Mini-Puzzle Platformer” as a diversion from more meaty games. However, the way the whole thing ends it’s hard not to feel just a little short changed, not from the money spent, but from the potential of what could have been.

The game starts out with a Schmup section which, theoretically, you could win the game right during its intro if you’re good enough. The more common outcome however is that you’ll die, and you crash land onto an alien planet equipped only with a teleport gun. Firing your gun onto most surfaces causes you to instantly appear where the bullet landed, and this is basically the only mechanic in the game. Later you get a gun that breaks things, which you use to clear out debris that’s in the way of your teleport gun, but that’s about it. The level design then carries the rest of the experience, bending the rules what you thought were the limitations of your abilities as you seek out your quarry and try to repair your ship.


Overall the game does a good job with its design. It never gets boring – and there’s a really fun boss that utilizes the teleport gun mechanics – but it also feels sort of incomplete. It would be amazing if they added in a few more mechanics, and really emphasized the open world Metroidvania aspect a little more – something more akin to what Supraland accomplishes with its similar puzzle focus. As-is the parts of the game that earns its Metroidvania tag feels sort of tacked on, and you’re often gated from back tracking to get missed collectables anyway. The reward for having a keen eye is that you can upgrade your ship for the inevitable retread of the Schmup section introduced at the beginning of the game. In my case I went straight through the experience with the intent to backtrack, only to be locked into the schmup fight unable to collect the power-ups the game teases. Left with the choice of starting over from the beginning (and retreading old puzzles) or “git gud”, I went with the latter.

I think that it’s safe to conclude that if you’re looking for a Metroidvania game, this one will likely not scratch that itch for most. If you’re a fan of puzzle platforming in general though, then it’s a pretty good choice. Similar to a ”Mini-Metroidvania” I’d recommend this to people that are looking for a taste of a Puzzle Platformer experience, but also don’t really want to commit to a longer game. At its price point “just good” is perfectly fine.

Final Score
3/5

122670817.review:
Don't let the opening SHMUP confuse you—this is a puzzle platformer. And it's got some pretty neat mechanics! I really like the teleport gun, as (in conjunction with the beams) it creates some really intricate platforming puzzles that require some pretty decent skill to pull off. It feels good when you pull them off!

I don't like the checkpoint density, though. There are a handful of locations in the game where it is REALLY easy to die performing some really intricate maneuvers, and you'll be sent back a screen or two—this is CRUSHING with how slow your walking speed is. There are even more locations where you'll have to just redo the entire screen because it won't entirely be clear if certain triggers remained activated when you died or not. You'll see what I mean if you play the game.

The combat is... eh. Not that interesting. The smaller enemies in the game would've worked better if you had to shoot them once, maybe twice, since that's how you're gonna be maneuvering around them, anyway. Not to mention, the bullets have a sort of awkward rhythm to when you can actually fire that's not really clear. Maybe a reload animation would help with this? That way timing could still be an element with some of the more interesting combat encounters, like against the big enemies that fire projectiles or against the final boss.

There's also some hidden collectibles, if that's your sorta thing. (Spoilers for the ending of the game) [spoiler]Supposedly they upgrade your ship in the final boss, which is a shoot-'em-up just like the opening sequence. I didn't have a hard time, though, and I only collected one. I don't think it even activated since I couldn't be bothered going through what's honestly a bit of a platforming gauntlet to get back to the upgrade guy, especially after I already went through it the first time only to learn I had to come back later.[/spoiler]

But, yeah, I think this game is worth the dollar I paid for it. Probably won't achievement hunt it, but it killed some downtime during work for me and I'm satisfied having beaten it.

In some places, a rather complex logical platformer, which requires the player to be diligent and accurate in their actions. Using the portal gun, the player must solve seemingly simple tasks to move the hero to the exit from the level.

120199071.review:
By itself the game would be a frustrating platform "puzzle" game with some exploration where you could get to explore a cool world. But the game seems obsessed with making you kill enemies in with a slow weak gun that is rather unentertaining and very repetitive. The enemies are simply an annoyance that only provide as another fail condition for no real reason. The game has a rather linear path that is very easy to accidentally follow if you decide not to backtrack. That would be fine if following this path didn't railroad you into the end of the game where you have to do yet more fighting in this portal-platforming game. Once beating the boss, YOU CANNOT GO BACK AND EXPLORE. Your passage is blocked on the left and a trigger on the right such that you cannot go back and explore the world unless you literally replay the entire game. The world you don't get to explore isn't that good to be fair. There is not one notable character in the entire game, which is sad as it makes interacting with 90% of characters redundant. 
Between frustrating mechanics, repetitive gameplay, and the janky hitboxes around this was not a good experience. It had so much potential but falls so sort.

There I was browsing the dollar or less indie-games when I came across this game for 40 cents. This game could definitely be sold for around $5. It is a basic metroidvania type game with decent music that is nice to listen to and very simple but well laid out puzzles, took me about over an hour to beat so it is a fun game to play and beat in one sitting. There are also some collectibles that you may miss in your first play through, so if you're into getting those there is definitely some replay value there.
Music 6/10 - It was very good but was only one song on a loop and can be hard on the ears after a while
Game-play 7/10 - I was very surprised on how smooth the mechanics were with controller. Using the teleport-er to navigate rooms is a fun idea that seams to be inspired by portal in a way. 
Story 6/10 - There isn't much there but for less then a dollar I wouldn't expect all that much. It was at least good enough for me to still be interested throughout. 
Overall I would give this game a 7/10. It is definitely worth what you pay for it and then some.

95445160.review:
Out of all the dollar games on Steam, Out there Somewhere is a true gem of 2d platformer-puzzle space game.  Beat it in 1 hour and 20 minutes using a game controller.  Difficulty is moderate-hard.  

- Gameplay has two parts.  One is a top-down 2d spaceship shoot 'em up.  The other, which comprises most of the game, is a platformer puzzle game.  You use a teleporting gun to get yourself through many dungeon rooms to get to the badguy at the end.  The controls are smooth.  

- The puzzles are tricky and some are harder than others.  I had to put the game down once because I was getting frustrated, til I realized the solution was right there.  So frustration in a good way.

- The world is memorable. There isn't much diversity in the enemies, but the variety of obstacles more than makes up for it.  The final boss is great, as are the aliens.  

- Non-linear.  While it seems like this is just another 'go from point A to B' platformer like the five million other dollar games out there, you will be pleasantly surprised.  There's no real sense of back tracking and you can get to the end boss in multiple ways.  Each replay can be different.  Don't feel like getting all the power cells this round or searching around for that one power up you're missing?  You don't have to.  

- Achievements.  There are a number of achievements that make replaying completely worth it.  

- Music.  The music draws you in with its midi vibes and will keep you shooting.



In summary, Out there Somewhere is a classic in the way CaveStory and VVVVVV are.  It's shorter in the way an arcade game is, and you'll die a ton.  This is the kind of game you can't hate, and will want to play multiple times.  Is it worth a dollar?  I think it's worth way more, and I hope to play anything else the developer does in the future.  You're not hitting the bottom of the barrel here.  This one's a keeper.

93674584.review:
Out There Somewhere is a 2D platformer game which would have fit right in back on the NES. While the graphics are probably a bit better than what would have been around back then in some places, on the whole this is a pixel graphics game whose gameplay harkens back to a much simpler time.

You play Yuri, a space cop in hot pursuit of Grigori, some sort of bad guy. You start out trying to shoot down his ship, fail, and then have to travel across the planet to confront him and collect a light orb to repower your ship and beat him down in the end-game.

The game is very simple. It claims to be inspired by Cave Story, Super Metroid, and Portal, but honestly it is its own thing, and not very much like any of those games. It is very linear, there isn’t much of a plot, and it is very centered around its central game mechanic – a teleportation gun.

When Yuri fires his gun, he gets teleported to wherever it hits, with whatever momentum he presently has being preserved. He cannot teleport if he is already right next to the surface he would be teleporting to.

He can also jump.

These two mechanics make up pretty much all of the gameplay in the game. You do eventually get a gun you can kill monsters and destroy certain blocks with partway through the game, which opens up a few more puzzles, but most of the game is centered around platforming with the teleportation gun – including one room towards the end of the game with no platforms in it at all, which the player scales by shooting shots across the room, landing, then jumping just as the shot hits the far wall.

The game cost 50 cents on sale, and is extremely short – this is the sort of thing you can beat in a single sit down. I was pretty heavily achievement and secret hunting and beat the game in 89 minutes my first time through. All that’s left at that point is trying to figure out how to acquire the last few secrets, many of which are pretty devious (such as requiring you to go through about a third of the game without saving once so you can die and respawn at the very start with the block-destroying gun, in order to acquire one of the secrets).

Was it worth 50 cents and an hour and a half of my time? I can’t say I wasn’t entertained by it, but it wasn’t high-quality entertainment – the game is decent enough as what it is, but it is not exactly aiming for the stars. If you like 2D platformers with simple, straightforward mechanics, this is probably a decent choice for you; if you like nice graphics, complex gameplay, a sophisticated story, or anything else like that, you’ll probably be disappointed by this game.

90109585.review:
Sometimes, you feel like playing something off the beaten path. You dig through Steam sales, sorting by new or lowest price, and through the piles of (well, not always) sub-par asset flips and other unfortunate materials, sometimes you find a diamond in the rough. Not to say that Out There Somewhere, a Metroidvania-like adventure game is anything akin to a masterpiece, but this charming little title is the perfect example of the gems you could find just by digging just beneath the surface.

Out There Somewhere is an adventure title with very light Metroidvania elements - though more akin to the original Metroid then any of its acclaimed successors. You play as Yuri, a starship pilot protecting ‘Mother Planet’ from Grigori, a pirate warlord who wrecks her ship, causing it to crash land on an unknown planet. From there, Grigori journey’s across the planet, using his ‘telegun’ to brave the deadly dangers, repair their ship, and defeat Grigori. It’s a very basic premise, but it’s serviceable enough to give context to Yuri’s journey. Despite that, the story doesn’t really progress beyond that - you get bibs and bobs from the dozen or so alien NPCs you run across, but outside of the fight with Grigori, the plot doesn’t progress at all. But like I said, that isn’t really a problem.

The main gameplay loop of Out There Somewhere is Grigori moving through screen after screen, with each screen having some specific puzzle or monster combination to deal with. For much of the game, Yuri’s only ‘weapon’ is a teleport gun that’ll warp him to wherever it ends up. A few elements in the game world mix up this basic gameplay loop - there are several kind of lasers involved in puzzles that interact differently with the telegun - red lasers will stop the shot, preventing Yuri from warping, blue will also stop them shot, but will cause Yuri to warp to them, and green lasers will cause the shot to move up the laser, depositing Yuri at the top of the laser. There are a few more minor mechanics then that, but for the most part that’s the main puzzle loop of Out There Somewhere. The loop doesn’t really evolve beyond that, though, and the game never really gets a chance to even attempt to evolve, as the experience is over in, probably on average, an hour and a half. Whilst it’s a nice length, especially for an indie title like this, it does feel a bit too short and I would’ve loved to see where else it could’ve taken. There are a number of collectables across the game world, used to upgrade both your ship and your on-foot HP, but I only found a handful across my playthrough, and overall I felt they were a little out of the way to find - but I could totally imagine myself giving it another run-through to try and track them down.

In some ways, I’d describe Out There Somewhere as a cousin of the original Portal. It’s short, simple, and very to the point, based around a single major mechanic or two that’ll pull you all through the game without boredom or frustration. Each of the puzzles in the game aren’t complicated enough to take you too long - I think there were only one or two that took more than five minutes for me to solve, and that was more down to me making platforming mistakes. Though, later in the game Yuri obtains a gun, and whilst he does use this to take down a few monsters in the game, it feels a bit like a tacked on mechanic more than anything, and personally I’d feel time would’ve been better spent fleshing out another mechanic with the teleport.
Additionally, there are only two real ‘fights’ in the game, one on the ground with the telegun/gauss gun, and another in space, mirroring the start of the game. Both of these fights aren’t terrible, but they don’t feel particularly inspired, especially the on-foot fight. The game feels fantastic as a little puzzle, but using those mechanics for combat just don’t feel nearly as good.

Adding to it’s simple gameplay loop is it’s wonderfully cute and low-key graphics. Out There Somewhere isn’t a particularly deep game in regards to it’s graphics, but the simplified, pixel-style art direction perfectly depicts a starkly barren world, populated by cute little critters and the member’s of Grigori’s villainous crew. There’s even a few genuine gorgeously, moody screens that gave me pause, forcing me to take a moment to appreciate the work the assumedly small team put into this charming little indie title.
The soundtrack is nothing to sneeze at, either, perfectly capturing Yuri’s adventure across the unnamed planet. It’s a wonderfully chill soundtrack, and with the night I played it being rather chilly, causing me to be wrapped in blankets, it was the perfect background to my evening playing Out There Somewhere. 
It’s chiptune based OST has a good number of head-swaying numbers, and whilst all of them fit their particular locale, I’d say it has that sort of issue where a bunch of the songs sound more than a little similar, bit that’s a rather nit-picky thing to say at the end of the day.

Out There Somewhere is a charming little indie title that proves that digging into Steam’s (or whichever provider you play through) listings beyond the front page can reward you with fantastic titles you’d never find elsewhere. Out There Somewhere provides a comfy experience with a well thought out, yet basic concept and mechanic that perfectly pulls through it’s well-paced journey. It’s not the biggest, most complex, or well-crafted game I’ve ever played - but I can see the love that went into Out There Somewhere, and the care so finely ingrained in every part of this game is enough to recommend to, well, pretty much anyone!

74244962.review:
Estamos ante un título muy interesante. Out There Somewhere es un videojuego independiente de plataformas en dos dimensiones y puzzles en el cual, su principal atractivo es el poder teletransportarse con la pistola del protagonista. Esto puede parecer simple, pero la razón por la que este juego ganó cierto renombre, desde mi punto de vista, es por lo bien que el desarrollador aprovechó y explotó esa mecánica. Los puzzles en un principio son bastante complejos y va a ser necesario que el jugador se pare un momento (bastante rato en mi caso) a analizarlos. En mi caso particular, conforme entendía el uso de la teletransportación en el juego, y como aprovecha la inercia, los puzzles se fueron aclarando. Esto se traduce en que tuve bastantes dificultades a la hora de avanzar en los primeros tramos del juego, y de la mitad para adelante se simplificó mucho.
Me gustaría aclarar que este juego me lo compré sin saber nada de él previamente, por curiosidad. Cuando lo empecé en realidad pensé que se trataba de un metroidvania con toques de plataformeo, por que había zonas que realmente no podía superar y me daba la sensación de que era necesaria una mejora para seguir. Es por esta razón que un puzzle tuve que averiguarlo en internet, pensando que había llegado a esa zona con algún recurso faltante, pero para mi sorpresa, es que estaba encarándolo mal.
No cuento esta triste historia respecto a mi manqueza por nada, sino para demostrar mi sorpresa de estar ante un producto de tanta calidad por un precio tan bajo. Realmente todos los puzzles pueden ser resueltos desde el principio. No es necesario mejoras, sino adquirir los conocimientos respecto a la teletransportación. Si un puzzle es muy avanzado para vos en ese momento, muy probablemente te enseñen de una forma indirecta, una mecánica o una forma particular de aprovechar el teletransporte más tarde.
La razón por la que el juego es tan barato, es debido a su corta duración. El juego puede ser completado en cuestión de una a dos horas. Sin embargo, incita bastante a la rejugabilidad ya sea para obtener todos los coleccionables o completar los logros.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2178939709
El último apartado del juego que me gustaría resaltar, es su banda sonora. Tiene una música muy adictiva inspirada en juegos retro que acompaña muy bien el transcurso de los niveles.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cc2S0g1aSxQ

66766701.review:
I've had Somewhere Out There installed on my PC for a while now but never really got into it until now, and I have to admit this is a lovely little game. It begins as an ordinary space-shooter before your ship crash-lands on an alien planet at which point it turns into a cute hybrid of Turrican and James Pond 3.

The aim is to navigate your way through a series of screens, all with their own chapter titles, while solving puzzles to help you progress. Your tools are a teleportation gun to help you jump around the screens, and a laser gun to kill hostile aliens and blast away blocks. All the while you must hunt for pieces of your ship.

It's very addictive and a lot of fun, though I only won 20 of the 36 achievements. I might play through it again to win some more as I never found all of the ship parts, but it's one of those games with too many "point of no returns". If the check points could be operated to send you back to previous check points then the game would be massively improved. Trading cards are also included.

Definitely worth getting.

Out There Somewhere, a little platformer/shooter/puzzler indie darling I got from one of those dollar bundles on the internet.
To be fair I went into this not expecting anything at all, after all most games you get from bundles like these tend to not be very good, or be on the shorter side, usually good for steam cards but little else.

However, I was very pleasantly surprised with this one. Although it definitely falls on the latter category (I beat it in less than an hour, netting myself one of the two "beat under X minutes" achievements without even realizing such achievements were there), it's one of those little fun experiences that do not overstay their welcome and keep you entertained with it's colorful, tasteful retro callback to games like VVVVVV or Knytt with the whole single screen "stages" and simple to learn, moderately tricky to master teleporting gameplay.

Talking about the plot of the game would do it a disservice, as the game is very short and the plot is nothing out of this world, however it's definitely worth it's pricetag. I got it in a bundle with other games, but really, I'd have purchased it right here had I known it was this cheap.

So yeah! Get it! Support the dev! Art is good, music is great, characters are memorable even though they'll come in and out of your life in less than an hour!

62167267.review:
[i]Out There Somewhere[/i] is a well-built game, and a pretty good time -- well worth the asking price. It's clever, but I wouldn't go so far as to call it an "[u]incredibly[/u] clever action-puzzle platformer," as the store page does. It's rewarding, and quite fun to play, but it's not remarkably challenging.

Most players will probably beat it within an hour on the first go, and it's not a terrible grind to dip back in for the remaining achievements -- which will probably take another 2 playthroughs. One is a speedrun achievement for beating the game in <20m, and even this is not terribly challenging once you know your way around. 

The platformer-puzzles involve: 
[list][*](1) Using your teleport gun to zip around the screen (when your shot hits a wall, you go there), 
and 
[*](2) Combining this with well-timed jumps. If you jump at just the right time, you'll still be moving up when you teleport to your new location, and that's basically how you move through complicated spots. Sometimes you'll need to chain this kind of move a few times in a row.
In addition:
[*](3) Some levels have up to 3 different laser beams running vertically through them, and these add some complexity by interacting with your teleport gun: red lasers will nullify your shot and nothing happens when it hits them -- but this isn't meaningless, because red lasers can block off whole regions of the board and restrict movement; blue will act like any other surface, so you'll warp to the laser when/where your shot hits it -- but unlike a normal surface, you can walk through lasers; green will redirect your shot up to the top of the laser, and then you'll teleport there.
To top it off:
[*](4) There are enemies and pitfalls that will kill you if you aren't careful. You gain a pea-shooter relatively early on, and will need to use it to get past enemies in a few places, and during the final boss battle. If you do die, you'll automatically restart at checkpoints that are pretty prevalent, and you don't lose anything.[/list]

Once you click "Play" in your Steam Library... and then click "play" again to get past an odd little launcher screen that offers you no options (?)... you can access the in-game settings to choose fullscreen or windowed. No more specific resolution options. There are 4 numbered volume settings for both music and FX (0=off, 4=max) which approximates a slider. You can have 3 save slots, though you don't really need them.

I had fun.

54934929.review:
[h1] The Metroidvania Review[/h1]
 [url=https://metroidvaniareview.com/2019/09/02/out-there-somewhere/] Scored Summary[/url] |  |                          [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/30503887/] Subscribe to our Curator	[/url]

[b]How Metroidvania is it?[/b]
Barely Comparable – There is technically an ability gate along the way, but otherwise this is a strictly linear puzzle platformer with optional pick-ups that make the final boss easier. 

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/MetroidvaniaReview/discussions/1/1735465524714511786/] Want to hear a different opinion, or want to share your own review? Check out our Forum here.[/url]

[h1]Full Review[/h1]
Some indie games just need a good idea to justify their reason for existing, and [i]Out There Somewhere’s[/i] teleport gun serves that purpose. During its short play time, the game builds on its core mechanics enough to feel satisfying just before it wears out its welcome. This makes it worthwhile at its budget price-point as a fun proof-of-concept and makes it a fun “Mini-Puzzle Platformer” as a diversion from more meaty games. However, the way the whole thing ends it’s hard not to feel just a little short changed, not from the money spent, but from the potential of what could have been. 

The game starts out with a Schmup section which, theoretically, you could win the game right during its intro if you’re good enough. The more common outcome however is that you’ll die, and you crash land onto an alien planet equipped only with a teleport gun. Firing your gun onto most surfaces causes you to instantly appear where the bullet landed, and this is basically the only mechanic in the game. Later you get a gun that breaks things, which you use to clear out debris that’s in the way of your teleport gun, but that’s about it. The level design then carries the rest of the experience, bending the rules what you thought were the limitations of your abilities as you seek out your quarry and try to repair your ship. 

Overall the game does a good job with its design. It never gets boring – and there’s a really fun boss that utilizes the teleport gun mechanics – but it also feels sort of incomplete. It would be amazing if they added in a few more mechanics, and really emphasized the open world Metroidvania aspect a little more – something more akin to what [i]Supraland[/i] accomplishes with its similar puzzle focus. As-is the parts of the game that earns its Metroidvania tag feels sort of tacked on, and you’re often gated from back tracking to get missed collectables anyway. The reward for having a keen eye is that you can upgrade your ship for the inevitable retread of the Schmup section introduced at the beginning of the game. In my case I went straight through the experience with the intent to backtrack, only to be locked into the schmup fight unable to collect the power-ups the game teases. Left with the choice of starting over from the beginning (and retreading old puzzles) or “git gud”, I went with the latter. 

I think that it’s safe to conclude that if you’re looking for a Metroidvania game, this one will likely not scratch that itch for most. If you’re a fan of puzzle platforming in general though, then it’s a pretty good choice. Similar to a ”Mini-Metroidvania” I’d recommend this to people that are looking for a taste of a Puzzle Platformer experience, but also don’t really want to commit to a longer game. At its price point “just good” is perfectly fine.  

3 out of 5

54727370.review:
So you have a game here that literally costs about the same, or less, as a cup of coffee. Probably not much to it, right? Well, sort of right. "Out There Somewhere" is a very short platformer with some mild Metroidvania elements to it. You can beat it in about 2 hours as I did, or in as little as 20 minutes for an achievement. But it's not a simple left to right trip to the end.

You have almost everything you need to complete the game at the start. But in a clever trick, there's a couple of hidden items at the start of the game, which you can can only access with the use of your only real weapon, which you don't get until partway through. What's more, is that if you play normally and uitlize checkpoints, you can't actually get back to the start to access those items. So you end up in an interesting little game of dodging checkpoints to get it all.

Outside of that, most of the items are straight forward, consisting of three health upgrades and some power cores which make your ship more powerful. Oh yeah, the game opens with a SCHMUP section and ends with one as well. So that's what you're leading up to. 

The music is decent, as is the art style. Although if you're like me you'll have to find someway to overlook how awful the sprite for your main character is. Because yeah it's just not visually appealing at all. The gameplay however, is very solid. It's so cheap you really don't have much excuse to not try it out.

50742708.review:
[b]Out There Somewhere[/b] is a cute little “Metroidvania-ish” puzzle platformer. It has a unique game mechanic with a teleportation gun and makes great use of that in its puzzle design. The toughest part of the game is actually finding your way around the world without the benefit of a map. The puzzles themselves are never too difficult, but sometimes you are required to string together two or even three jumps in rapid succession to scale a difficult piece of platforming.  The game has a nice retro style and is very well done. The game is rather short as it takes only a little over an hour to complete a first run, but I didn’t mind. It reminded me a bit of The Swapper.
The soundtrack is also remarkably good. Unfortunately, the soundtrack is not on Spotify, but it is available as a cheap DLC in Steam. Remarkably, the soundtrack is also available on bandcamp.com ([url=https://miniboss.bandcamp.com/releases]https://miniboss.bandcamp.com/releases[/url]) for a substantially higher price of 5 USD, but this version includes some additional tracks and alternative versions of the tracks included in the OST on Steam.
As the game’s ending basically promised a sequel, I wondered what other games this developer (Miniboss) had made, but found none on Steam. The publisher turned out to be EQGames, which have published one of my other favorite platformers, AirScape.

49470825.review:
Game is light on platforming and heavier on the puzzling factor.
The game is rather short, but the increasing difficulty of the puzzling aspect will slow you down.
Some rooms are guaranteed to stump you on your first play through, requiring you to seek help.
You will also require very fast reaction times and hand dexterity to complete later puzzles.

For the above reasons I cannot recommend this game to everyone.

Also, I completed the game in 2016 but didn't realise due to the low achievement count.
Now in 2019 I have finished the game a second time and only attained just above 50% achievements.
It's not the type of game that you feel inclined to play over and over again.

I feel the tag Metroidvania is used loosely here. The game is strictly linear and you aren't exactly seeking out items or abilities. The puzzles just get more complex and you have to adjust to them as a player using your starting gear. Completing one rooms puzzle to the following room is not Metroidvania.

If on the other hand, you are looking for a difficult experience. Then I recommend you give it a go.

48883112.review:
[h1]Here's what you do:[/h1]
Out There Somewhere is a 2D puzzle platformer where you use a teleportation gun to traverse environments. There are enemies, but they are mostly there for you to avoid death. The game starts out with a space shooter segment where you are supposed to lose to the boss. After that is when the game starts.

[h1]What I like:[/h1]
+ Fun and unique mechanic of the teleport gun which keeps your momentum for platforming challenges.
+ Awesome music.
+ Well-hidden collectibles which add power to your character.
+ Interesting achievements which are not limited to simple game completion.

[h1]What I don't like:[/h1]
- The fake out start can be frustrating as the opening boss seems beatable even though it isn't and you are supposed to lose. When you refight the boss at the end, you don't seem any more powerful than before.
- I wish the real final boss before going back to your ship was a longer fight or had a second form.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
The game only takes about an hour to beat the story, but I had a lot of fun spending a total of 4 hours to get all the achievements.

[h1]Want to see more about this game? Watch this:[/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1650441871

48110855.review:
Pues resulta que es un muy buen juego de apenas dos horas de duración, o incluso menos si eres más hábil y no haces pausas.

Está compuesto de pequeñas secciones de shoot 'em up de naves espaciales y, en su mayoría, una mezcla de plataformas con disparos y mecánicas tipo Portal, pero usando el tema de la pistola de portales de otra manera, y añadiendo unas paredes de colores que modifican el resultado de disparar un portal ahí. Las secciones de plataformas y puzles están muy bien diseñadas, el control está pulido y es ágil. El juego asume que vas a fallar muchas veces y trata de ser lo más dinámico posible, ya que en alguna sección vas tener que probar y probar unas cuantas veces hasta que adivines y te salga lo que hay que hacer para superarla.

Gráficamente es sencillo y en líneas generales no es bonito, lo mejor igual los personajes y las viñetas de la historia (en inglés, francés y creo que portugués). Historia que, por cierto, cabría escrita en una servilleta, está bien sin más. La música tipo 8-bit es algo pesada (aunque variada) y agradece el bajarle el volumen, pero le pega al juego y de todos modos apetece escucharla (bajo) mientras juegas.

Los logros son para quien quiera disparar 500 veces a no se qué, pasar el juego sin guardar... Es lo único que añade rejugabilidad una vez acabado el juego, pero de todos modos es un juego muy divertido y, aún pasando de los logros, es un juego que entendería querer acabárselo más veces.

En definitiva, un juego muy divertido. Yo lo compré (rebajado) por 0,39 y mereció mucho la pena. ¡Recomendado!

[h1] First Impressions [/h1] 
With this game only costing $1 full price, and with such favorable reviews, I saw no reason not to get Out There Somewhere (OTS) when it showed up in a bundle. It looked like an interesting platformer, and the space theme made me curious how the game would play. I played the game years ago on my laptop, using the keyboard to control it, and though I could beat the game, I knew I wasn't set up to earn all the achievements. Coming back to it again, this time with a controller, I got all of the achievements and cleaned up the game easily enough. It was fun to play on a better set-up for my preferences, and reminded me why I had put up with a less than ideal control scheme in the first place. 


[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
Upon crash-landing on an unfamiliar world, you'll seek to get a McGuffin, which will let you fix your ship and get back to familiar territory. You start the game with a teleport gun, which lets you shoot out glowing beacons that will transport you to whichever wall you hit. This will be necessary to get past different obstacles and make tricky jumps. 

After a while, you'll find the Gauss gun, which is just a basic firearm that lets you kill enemies. It takes 2-4 shots to destroy them, but doing so is quite satisfactory, as many platformers with mechanics like this would make you dart around them with no way to attack. You actually will do so at the beginning, but it's not long before you're able to fight back. However, though there are enemies, the focus of the game is much more on finding secrets and clever platforming. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2138738192
[h1] Controls [/h1] 
There are only a few moves in OTS. Movement is controlled with the 'L joystick.' Firing the teleport gun is done by pressing 'X,' while shooting the Gauss gun is done by pressing 'B.' Jumping is controlled with 'A.' The controls are responsive and work well, though it sometimes feels clunky making the platforming work right, with most of the problem stemming from timing. For instance, when you shoot a wall, you can jump right as you teleport there, but the timing can feel a bit off. Also, in order to make a jump, you have to be standing on ground before you teleport, or else you'll only fall. It functions correctly and consistently, but as your jumps aren't that high and you'll have to fire across the entire screen sometimes, it can be tricky. 


[h1] Story [/h1] 
You play as a space cop who is chasing after a nefarious outlaw named Grigori. Starting the game, you'll be in a shoot-out with them that leads to a mandatory loss, getting shot out of the sky, and crash into a nearby planet. You'll have to traverse the place on foot in hot pursuit, trying to make sure he doesn't slip away. There are some optional secret items and routes, and you'll converse with local denizens, but there's not much else to the story. You don't get any background on the situation, any of the characters, or what justice would look like if you captured Grigori. 


[h1] Graphics [/h1] 
The game is made with pixel art, and uses square tiles to build the environment, with most of them being replicated heavily to create the setting. However, there's enough variety and little touches to change up the visuals and make it look more natural. Because of the suit, the protagonist winds up looking like an alien himself, and I don't know if that was a clever design choice (humans would be aliens on other worlds) or simply the effect of their design. For a cheap game, the graphics look quite nice. 


[h1] Sound Design [/h1] 
As you progress through OTS, different songs will cue up and play. I believe they're related to certain locations, though I don't know how the developers broke different regions apart from each other. There's a decent variety in the tempo and style of the music, which is nice to see in both a short, space-themed game, but also a budget one. The sound effects that play from your two guns are distinct from one another, and make sense for the functions they serve. The default volume settings are loud, but are easy to adjust in the options. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2138739219
[h1] Pros [/h1] 
🌟 OTS blends platforming with a small amount of puzzle mechanics in a way that's not too challenging, but adds more than simply jumping around. 
🌟 Enemies don't prove to be too annoying to deal with. That's been an irritation in other platformers I've played. 


[h1] Cons [/h1] 
❌ When replaying the game, the captain's logs that pop up in several of the early areas is really frustrating with how intrusive they are. They do contain tutorial information and character development though. 
❌ The game ends unsatisfactorily, with a tease that the game will continue in a sequel. However, there's been no sign of a sequel emerging, and it was released back in 2016. 
❌ A few jumps prove to be frustrating to pull off consistently, though the game is mostly enjoyable. 


[h1] Tips [/h1]
🔍 If you intend to earn all the achievements, unless you want to do so spoiler free, it's not worth collecting the optional items during a first or casual playthrough. You'd instead want to consult a guide, know how to acquire them all, and make an attempt where you get all in one run. Earning them all will also require multiple playthroughs. 
🔍 Teleport jumping is something you'll want to get a handle on earlier than later, as it's mandatory to beat the game. 
🔍 There are some handy videos showing how to earn the achievements and find the hidden items. 


[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1] 
OTS takes a while to beat the first couple of times you play it, depending on how much you explore and try to uncover secrets. However, there are alternative ways of traversing the early sections of the game, which uncover secret items and lead to a significant reduction in your time. These will be necessary to earn all the achievements, and is enjoyable to play through since you're oblivious to it the first time through. 

Unfortunately, as you replay OTS, it demonstrates how small and short the game really is, which I don't think is something you want to highlight in a cheaper game, as it disincentives people getting it. This winds up being a short-coming, but OTS is a good game otherwise. I'd recommend it, in spite of some quirks, just know it'll only give more playtime through repeated playthroughs, which would likely only matter for achievement hunters.

43596989.review:
This game is really fun, you have a gun that shoots portal lasers and when they hit a wall you teleport to that wall and its really pretty cool.

Then you get the second gun. It's a normal-ass gun that just shoots bullets to damage things, except using it is the least fun thing I have possibly ever experienced while shooting a gun in a video game. It takes way too many hits to kill enemies, and it shoots once per second (That's not an exaggeration, it's literally once per second.) so if you miss with these tiny-ass bullets it feels like it takes forever before you can shoot again.

Enemies that, in any other game, would be satisfying to kill, are a frustrating distraction from the actual fun part of the game. I hated using the second gun so much that I tried to avoid killing things as much as possible because it was more fun that way, but that meant every room where you were required to kill anything became a CHORE. 

Then I got to a boss battle. I don't know if it's the only boss battle or if it's the end of the game or whatever, because I won't be playing past this boss. There is NO health bar, so in addition to using the awful un-fun gun that drains enjoyment from the game, you have to just GUESS how much longer the fight will take. Also, the boss itself is annoying to dodge. It's not HARD to dodge his attacks, it's just so painfully slow that I died from trying to dodge attacks before he shot them. It doesn't help that taking one hit kills you. (I had 2 hearts, but taking damage almost always knocks you into either lava or something else that kills you, so the second hit doesn't matter at all.)

This entire game would be 1000000x better if the gun shot 4 times as fast and bosses had healthbars.

TL;DR: The platforming is excellent, fighting enemies is a painfully boring/frustrating distraction from the platforming.

43552699.review:
Out There Somewhere is a pixel puzzle-platformer game, where you play as Yuri, an astronaut that gets stranded on an unknown planet. You must find the parts to fix your ship and also find Grigori, who is the enemy of your people. With your trusty teleporter gun (and also a gun that kills monsters that you get later on), you must traverse the strange landscape to seek help and intel. I finished the game in about ten hours, but my first playthrough had been about three.

I liked what the game had to offer! The music was interesting to listen to (I only wish there had been more increments for volume adjustment other than just setting it as numbers one through three), the character and monster designs were cool, and I very much enjoyed the story, even if it was a simple one. 

The mechanics of the puzzle-platforming was a bit difficult to get used to, but I did start to get more comfortable with it as time went on. There are quite a few secret areas and collectables that will improve both your health meter and your ship.

There were times when I would get frustrated with the game when I couldn't get to certain platforms, but that was more on me and my reflexes, rather than anything inherently wrong with the game. I never got stuck in a room for very long though (I know this because the achievement for being stuck in a room for eight minutes never triggered for me during my legitimate playthroughs - I had to force it by standing still for that amount of time).

Overall, it was a short and sweet experience that was enjoyable and engaging. I like the aspects it brought to the table and the world it built. The puzzles were just the right amount of challenge to make you think a bit, but weren't tedious. The game isn't that expensive so I recommend it to those interested in a little puzzle-platform experience.

Tags: Platformer
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: I found the teleportgun mechanic hard to handle. Short game. Teleport gun yourself through walls and foes as you puzzle-platform screen after screen. Good lookling pixelart. 

While there might be a fun gameplay loop for those who get a solid handling of the controls, I did not like that the game would not allow me to initiate teleport with a trigger button, instead teleporting the character when the bullet from the teleport gun hits an obstacle.

What makes matters worse is that you are often expected to press jump just as you teleport, and you can sort of... jump in the air, right after teleporting, to actually climb platforms. I found this unintuitive and the magins to execute it felt a bit too tight.

Animated portraits and music were nice, but everything else was rather standard or a bit meh and the game is a bit of a one trick pony, so if you do not like the first 10 minutes chances are you will not want to stick around for the hour it would take for a skilled player to beat it, probably much longer if you play it as a chore and do not handle the mechanics well.

Might as well remove this for declutter, it is not terribly valuable, the entertainment value in my case is very low and even if it was a good game its short duration makes it hard to justify occupying a permanent spot in library.

43390861.review:
A cheap and cheerful little game that can be beaten in 60 minutes (or in 20 or less if you use a guide / YouTube video).  The mechanics are well-executed, if not terribly groundbreaking (you shoot a projectile to warp around the screen, and can use momentum from jumps to get places you couldn't otherwise reach).  The comparison that immediately came to my mind, fairly or not, was of a 2D "Portal."  

With that said, I have a few small complaints about the game.  The sprites are cute, but the story is as contrived as can be.  Also, the beginning and end shoe-horn in a shoot 'em up game (a la Gradius or R-Type, though significantly less difficult).  These sections were considerably easier than the rest of the game, and much more forgettable, too.  The only other complaint that comes to mind is that, with all the available power-ups, the final boss, [spoiler]which comes in two phases: a side-scrolling form that uses the mechanics of the main game and a shoot 'em up section like the game's opening,[/spoiler] is [i]really[/i] easy if you have all the power-ups.

Ultimately, this is a fun little game that punches above its weight for its price point.  It is worth checking out if you like puzzle-platformers with a hint of action.

Vaya sorpresón. Es el típico juego que compré para gastar algunos euros acumulados por cromos, del que no esperaba demasiado por su precio, y me lo he pasado genial de principio a fin.

El juego consiste en avanzar por una serie de pantallas utilizando una pistola que te teleporta con sus disparos. Más adelante encontrarás también un arma convencional que destruye cosas y mata enemigos, pero la gracia del juego es resolver los puzzles de teleportación usando a veces un poco de pensamiento lateral.

No es largo (a mí me ha llevado unas 2h) pero estamos hablando de un juego que cuesta menos de un euro y que si lo pillas de rebajas lo puedes llegar a comprar por 40 céntimos. Además veo que es rejugable porque mirando por alguna guía veo que no he visitado todas las pantallas, cosa que intuía claramente porque un personaje del final me pedía unas piezas que no tenía para mejorar mi nave en el enfrentamiento final. 

La estética retro está muy bien aprovechada. Creo que en este caso le añade algo de encanto. Y tiene una jugabilidad equilibrada: es fácil pero a veces vas a tener que pensar el movimiento. Una música acorde con su estética, muy resultona. 

Un producto muy barato con unas sorprendentes dosis de calidad.

43247033.review:
I just finished Out There Somewhere and I've gotta say, this was a REALLY fun platformer. I love the fast pace and the fun mechanics, and the music is great!  It was quite a short game, but it didn't feel like it was rushed in anyway and I do feel satisfied after completing it.

Pros:
-Unique platforming mechanics that open up oppurtunities for tons of fun puzzles.
-Fast respawn EVERY SINGLE TIME! You die a lot trying to solve the puzzles, so this is really important and they've nailed it.
-It's simple. This game only has a few mechanics that are introduced, and they make use of them beautifully in every level. Unlike in games that have too many mechanics, you find yourself having to use each tool in every single area.
-The music is good - short loops that are great to listen to at first, and during my playthrough they didn't get annoying after a couple attempts.
-A badass final boss battle in space was pretty fun.

Cons:
-Some people might find it too short.
-The story was ok, but nothing special. Most of the focus was clearly on the gameplay here.
-The cutoff points for backtracking for missed items wasn't as clear as I would have liked. I missed a few. Guess I'll have to play it again. :)

Overall: 8.5/10

41768578.review:
This game is a lot like VVVVVV, so if you like that, you'll probably like this. The gimmick here is a teleporter gun, which allows for some fun platforming puzzles.

The difficulty curve is well-tuned and there are collectibles to add additional challenge if you want it. I would have liked a few more levels, but what's here is good.

Though the platforming is great, the action elements I found kind of boring. The ground combat is slow and generally easy, and the space combat feels like a tacked-on minigame. I think the game would be improved by deleting space combat and ground enemies.

There are some minor quality-of-life issues, though no dealbreakers. I'm playing on MacOS with a DualShock 4, and oddly the menu key is mapped to the right trigger with seemingly no option to remap. Awkward, but tolerable.

Overall, one of the best hard platformers I've played, despite its flaws.

39082454.review:
I found this game while looking in my discovery queue and saw it was on sale for super cheap.

I haven't gotten too far but it's maybe one of the best games I've ever played.

A lot of it comes down to the writing as they the entire idea is you're a hellbringer of the apocolyse suddenly forced to save the world just so you can destroy it. For a game this cheap, you would be right in assuming that it would be as crindgy as a Steam reviewer trying to be funny. But no, it turns out to be genuinely good. It's won't win any awards but I found myself chuckling at how well they decided to roll with such an absurd pretense.

As far as the gameplay, it's an RPG done in the style of Dragon Quest. It's simple and straight forward to play. However, there are tweaks that make battles go way faster, you get a full heal after every battle, and you can start a battle whenever want. The result is an RPG that you can go through pretty fast. It's nothing special at the end of the day but the range of spells and status effects such as insanity! Cause why not?

At the end of the day, it's cheap and worth playing through to see what happens next.

38105788.review: This game is the perfect length because it's meant to be played at least three times. No added padding to try to extend play time but deeper than a short mobile game. There are so many layers of depth to this game. Each play through is a different experience. The first play through acts as a tutorial/puzzle game as you explore how the one portal mechanic can be reused in clever ways. The puzzle element comes from not fully understanding the portal mechanic in the beginning but learning it is so fun. Then the second play through doesn't lose its fun now that you've solved the puzzles. It's more about exploration as you apply the skills you've learned from the first playthrough. You realize there's this whole other game you didn't know was there until you had fully grasped the depth of the portal gun. Then the third+ play through becomes a satisfying test of your skills as you try to unlock the final achievement and beat the game in under 20 minutes. Really good use of achievements by the way. The game is so short that trying to unlock the final acheivement is not frustrating. Even after I unlocked the acheivement, I sometimes find myself beating it again when I want a platformer and I've only got 20 mintues to play it.

37986034.review:
At first glance, Out there Somewhere appears to be a simple Puzzle Platformer with a somewhat charming pixel aesthetic.
In reality... That's exactly what it is, though I don't feel that's actually too big a detractor, as while it is very simple, it does it all fairly well. 

The game's layout reminds me of 'Switchblade' for the Amiga. A fairly linear platformer, though there are a good amount of instances in which you can branch out and find upgrades. There are a fair few, though they're never far enough from the main path to feel like backtracking to get the main game is a chore. How much they're all worth getting is questionable, as for all the cores, you don't get much more than an upgrade to make an already fairly easy final boss easier and the upgrade to the gun feeling like it only exists to make the boss right before the final boss completely pointless. The health upgrades feel like they're the only ones worth it.

The mechanics are solid and fun, and for the most part, the level design compliments it. The main gimmick of the game is the teleport gun, which is sort of like a one-shot portal gun. You shoot it, and you teleport to where the shot lands. The reason I use Portal as the comparison specifically is that the game mimics its 'Momentum is kept' idea, where if you're jumping when the shot hits, you'll be jumping when you get to where it was, along with falling, etc. It's fun and interesting, and aside from a few screens, it all blends together superbly. There will be a couple instances where the puzzles might feel a little too dickish, but if you sit down and think about all possible options, you should be able to get through, it's not horribly brain taxing. 

The music is certainly a high point of the game though, and I can certainly see why they chose to make it DLC to get a little more cash out of those who want to support the developers a bit. For those who don't, they can just listen to it on Bandcamp (Although for those who want to /buy/ it on Bandcamp, it's 5 dollars, which is a little perplexing). 

The story is definitely the game's weakest point though, and there's really not much more to it than what's described on the store page. No plot twists or anything. I won't spoil it for those who do want to experience it, since even an incredibly simple story such as this can be enjoyable to some, and the game does manage to give you more of a goal than just escaping the planet, but it's really nothing award-winning. That said, this game was made (According to the developers) to be a 'fun game based on what we used to play in the 90’s,' even following up by saying that It has a very simple story.

Also worth noting is the game's length. I don't believe in Steam's refund policy of a two hour time limit, as it kind of undermines a lot of fun games that are shorter than that. Most SHMUPs, some short story based games such as Grow Home (Haven't played the game myself, but has quite a following, and I hear the main story can be beaten in just shy of that time), hence why I'm not saying it's the weakest point for myself, though I know it can be for others. The game is fun enough to justify it in my eyes, but it only took 50 minutes for my first playthrough, and about thirty minutes for my second, which was an attempt at more of a speedrun.

I did get it on sale a long while back, only playing it now that I'm going through my backlog and I recall it going frequently on sale for about 50 cents, and for that, it's worth it. I'd still argue that's it's worth for two dollars. If the length throws you off, I'd recommend it on sale, and if it doesn't bother you, it's a whole-hearted recommendation otherwise. Far from perfect, but a fun time nonetheless.

36550181.review:
I'm sorry to give a negative impression about this game, since it comes at only 1€, the minimum price here, and it's overall not that bad, but I wasn't able to enjoy it.
Graphics are retro-style, but badly rendered to me.. I don't know, I think this is a bad way to recreate '90s arcade games. Plus, there's no story and the game's quite short. Centered on three buttons, the most important being the teleport one; the other ones get you to shoot and to jump, nothing else. The teleport command will be of course fundamental in solving the small puzzles.
I'm feeling quite lonely 'cos it seems that everyone loved this XD
It's also easy apart from being short anyways, and it can take maybe two hours only, more if you're hunting for achievements like I'm doing. 
Apart from the very first part, in which you're teleported into an arcade horizontal shoot 'em up, the rest of the game is a normal platformer as you have seen thousands of them. And the shoot 'em up short sectiosn are really really bad.
As I said, there's no plot at all.. the enemies crashed your airship and you've got to obtain your revenge. 
All of these things summed up don't make a bad game, but to me as an adult gamer seem overall a copy of a copy of games I was already playing in the '90s, nothing really new is added and even if the price is low, you can play lots of free platformers way better and longer than this, with better soundtracks too.
It seems that when you are getting used to the mechanisms (which are as I said the same as many other older games) the game's already finished. There are no upgrades or other "new" things, and the store page mentions lots of masterpieces that really can't be compared to this one!
I also read of guys who finished the game in half an hour or something, and for 1€ it's not enough, especially considering the fact that there's no plot and there's also no replay value since it's the same and you can't do that much else.
For some reason this game should be extremely popular due to the hundreds of reviews it has. Anyways, to me it isn't worth 1€ for its value and its general content.
If you're into 2D retro arcade platformers, I'd suggest you to get this on sale 'cos at full price (and maybe it costs more in other currencies? I read reviews talking about 2$!) it isn't worth it at all.

34738358.review:
Space, a portal gun, a rapid fire machine gun and tons of rooms to traverse through will create this very excitig adventure. MiniBoss has created a short, pixalated adventure/platformer game where you control Yuri, a well-known space police offcier that has to escape the planet he's on in order to save humanity.

Pros
- Clever Level Design
A good chunk of these levels can be solved in a multitude of ways. These ways will make you think outside of the box because if you don't, there is a good chance you might be stuck for a while. You can find ways to get through the levels quicker than before or find other ways to avoid doing the levels. You just have to find the secrets and tricks of each room, and like I said, they are very clever.

- Challenging Levels
Alongside clever level design, there are some that require a bit of patience and brainstorming before completing. The game has some rather difficult levels that stops you from speedrunning it through. Of course, if you beat it already it would be easier to do a second run, but the game offers both side of the spectrum in each of its levels, easy and hard.

- Retro Soundtrack
The music actually goes well with the game. It has a pixelated feeling to it and it changes to match each level setting. Reminds me when I use to play the original Mario Bros, it bring great memories to me.

- Smooth Controls
To me, I thought the controls were smooth and reactive, which save me a couple times during the game. It may take awhile to get use to, but you'll get use to it and continue forward. Your main concern will be getting used to the portal mechanics because there are some levels that you have to use the portal gun and it reacts differently to different objects in the game. In the end, the controls are crisp and quick.

Other than those, this game does have its fair share of cons, but most of them can relate to each other.

Cons
- Repetitive Gameplay
The first time through is fun, but going back and doing a second run may cause some problems. There is no extras things when beating the game, it takes you back through everything again with no change. It makes sense if your trying to get all the secrets hidden in each levels, but then after a while it becomes a chore going through each level again and again.

- Short Game
The game can be completed in under an hour or even in twenty minutes (these are achievements by the way). It sucks that if your really good at platforming game, you can rush probably through this game and be done with it. Really, its a very short game, even when finding all of its secrets.

- Minimal Content
There isn't to much to offer in the game, all you get is a few item that will help you get through the game and that' it. The game has some unique gamelevel mechanics, but other than that, there isn't much that will be remembered after you finished the game.

- Other Minor Problems
There are some achievements that require you to go out of your way and spend quite a bit of time to complete them. I had to use a couple of walkthroughs to help me get them, which took me a while.

My Verdict Of The Game
8/10

It may had been an Indie game, but there could have been more work put into it. However, it has unique elements to make stand out and be memorable to some people. The story was quite straigthforward, which I liked, but the gameplay was also quite straightforward as well. This made it nothing to special except for its portal mechanics, which I thought was pretty clever and it gave me a challenge to overcome. Other than the gameplay, the game wasn't anything too special, but it was solid and quite fun to play. To me, the soundtrack stands out the most to me since it fits the billet perfectly. It need a bit more work, but overall a memeorable game to me and to the people who supported this.

33393094.review:
[b] If you are looking for a game with a fleshed-out story and a lot of replayability, this isn't the game for you. [/b]
The first time I beat the game, it only took me 90ish minutes and my most recent run took 14ish minutes. However, do not let this stop you from gettting this game, because at its core, [b] Out There Somewhere is a very solid puzzle platformer. [/b] The main drawing point of this game is the use of the Teleport Gun, which, as its name implies, teleports you wherever its bullet hits. There are many unique and clever puzzles throughout the game that utilize this gimmick to its fullest. On the other hand, combat is extremely basic and nothing to write home about. The game looks and sounds great thanks to its retro art style and soundtrack. Steam achievements do provide some replayability, which can be gotten within 4/5 playthroughs, and guides are available if you would like to obtain them faster. While there are many elements of Out There Somewhere that are mediocre at best, its puzzle platforming alone is worth it.

TLDR - Very fun puzzle platformer utilizing teleportation, very cheap, but extremely short and very little replayability

33382883.review:
[h1]Teleport Fun![/h1]

This was an unexpected surprise. I went in expecting a cheap little platforming game and what I got was an adventure game that was short and very sweet.

The story is quite basic, but you start out in a scrolling shooting game and wind up stranded after the battle on a planet. From there you explore with the use of a teleport gun, all to find your nemesis and escape.

The teleoprt gun is pretty slick, and I honestly can't think of a lot of games off the top of my head that emulated this type of 'metroidvania' style game play using such an item. I'm sure they're [i]out there somewhere,[/i] but I haven’t seen them. That said, it is a slick mechanic executed flawlessly in this game. The gun fires a beam that reacts differently depending on whether or not it hits a solid surface, crosses beams of different colors, or passes through bars. There's not a lot to explain here, it all becomes very evident as you play.

Mastering the use of the teleport gun and jumping becomes essential, and then second nature. The game trains the player through elegant and simple level design that will show newcomers a way through and experienced players a lot of previously missed shortcuts.

The games graphics are really excellent. [i]I myself experienced a bug that made it all look like a bad Atari Game, but there is a feature with [u]ATI/AMD[/u] video cards called [u]'Mipmap level detail'[/u]. The forum had some insight, but in my case, rather than going into Catalyst Control Center I had to right-click the tray icon and go through a few menu trees to find the option. [u]Setting it from 'High performance' to 'Performance'[/u] did the trick.[/i] Once I had the visuals working right I could make out all the little details that had before been a terrible blur.

Graphically this is like a really well made Sega Master System game. I really enjoyed the style and felt just a little nostalgic for the old 8-bit era games. The game play falls into this category as well, being both clever and classic.

Sound effects and music are also well done, and in the same vein of those 8-bit era games.

The game is very short and can be completed in under 20 minutes (my record is 16 minutes), but has a good amount of replay value if you want to explore, discover a handful of hidden areas, and maybe see how fast you can complete the game itself. The game makes no mistakes, the player does. When I kept getting killed it was my fault for not paying attention to what was going on, or for goofing off. The game doesn't punish the player, but it totally rewards good skill and timing.

I only used my controller to play this and found absolutely no problems.

I've clocked over 8 hours and enjoyed every hour spent here. I would love to see more, even a sequel, but as it stands this is a solid platforming game worthy of your time.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Nice graphic style
    [*]Good sound
    [*]Challenging but not frustrating
    [*]Tight controls
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Short
    [*]Visual bugs for some
[/list]

[b]Verdict: 8/10[/b]

Short but brilliant experience. Recommended, especially if on sale.

33093748.review:
I wanted to like this - as far as retro 2d pixel scrollers go, it's not the worst of a bad bunch.

They did some hard yards here - the game displays and works properly if you have a PC from 2017 (eg, 4K monitor, Win10K etc).   The controls even work on both keypad and Steam controller, so you're not forced to unplug the Steam controller then immediately write an angry review.   Excellent. 

What makes this game cool is that it has both a shmup mode and a platformer mode.  What makes this game uncool is that these are both retro pixel versions of those modes.  But again, tolerance for at least accepting modern PCs exist.

However, overall the controls are janky and annoying - if you don't jump at the exact correct pixel, you get punished.  Also, despite tremendous effort to make the game work stably on modern systems, it's still retro pixel rubbish.

I think what has happened here is a bunch of talented and excellent developers who understood QA and testing and getting it to work before it's launched got hired by a bunch of baristas who convinced them that Starbucks was just their day job and they should write a game for them, and no hiring graphic artists so they don't have to do 2D pixel art is unneccessary, and thus a dead game in a flooded 2D retro pixel market was born. 

I don't know what to say here - the guys who did the QA and technical stuff?  Go get a job in the industry - you are worth a decent salary.  The idiots who thought a 2D pixel crapfest was worth dumping into a saturated market?  Here is my pointed down thumb, stop holding talented developers back!  To sum it up best - there is no point in being the tallest of all midgets.

32049410.review:
+Fun, challenging platforming with tight controls
+Teleport gun is a cool gimmick

-Extremely short, with very little content and replayability
-Lazy level design that misses the point of the Metroidvania style 
-Lazy presentation
-Ham-fisted shmup sections at the beginning and end don't work
-Awkward dialogue

Above all, this game feels lazy. It feels like the dev wanted to make a metroidvania but quit halfway through because it was too much work. It is so short. One hour and I finished my playthrough. No real replayability either; I could probably squeeze another playthrough out of it to try and get to more "secrets" and upgrades, but the game isn't fun enough to make me want to sit through it again just for that. The metroidvania-style screen-to-screen progression is wasted when your game is this linear and small; it just comes off as a level design cop-out. The upgrades are uninspired and the one that actually affects gameplay, the gun, is implemented really awkwardly. It pretends to be a metroidvania, but doesn't actually succeed at anything a metroidvania does, and we're left with a platformer with clunky levels that just feels unfinished. It's like a kid stomping around in dad's big shoes, but with none of the charm. Meanwhile, it has two shmup sections, one at the beginning and one at the end. They're bland and rather slow-paced with wonky hitboxes, and they don't really tell you when you've gotten hurt. 
The presentation of the game is mediocre across the board, neither offending nor dazzling. Mediocre "retro-style" pixel art and music only make the game seem even lazier. The levels look like they were made in a level editor for an actual complete game - outside of background setpieces, almost every single part of the environment is blocks with repeating textures. From a visual standpoint, this game is just bigger, uglier Terraria. The sound effects are unremarkable, and while the music isn't inherently bad, it's extremely loud even on the lowest setting and gets grating fast. 

I do have to give this game one thing: the platforming is fun. As a puzzle-platformer, this game shines. It's challenging, but not frustrating, and the wide variety of things you can do with the teleport gun really makes movement in the game feel free. The controls are tight and responsive (with the exception of firing your gun feeling a bit clunky at times), and I enjoyed the mix of puzzle solving and technical skill that the game encouraged. Unfortunately, this alone just can't support the weight of the game's flaws.

Out There Somewhere is based on a good core concept with the teleport gun, but it doesn't go anywhere with it. If there was more content and the game encouraged exploration better, it could be a solid metroidvania. If it ditched the metroidvania level style and instead had actual levels more like your average puzzle platformer, it could be a solid platforming game. If this whole game was only the first world, and the game had more worlds like it with more and more challenges, upgrades, and progression broken up with shmup sections, the game could succeed as the weird mix that it is. But as it stands, Out There Somewhere is little more than a proof of concept.  As cheap as $2 is, there are better ways to spend your money. It's a decent experience if you get it on a good sale or in a humble bundle, though.

Out there somewhere is a really interesting 2D platfomer where you have to use a portal gun to move on to the next level. The game has a really great soundtrack and overall a pretty interesting idea. It has a pretty boring story but that's ok in my opinion.

The big reason why I can't recommend this game is because of it's "portal jumping" mechanic, in the game you can't double jump so what you have to do is shoot your portal gun towards the wall and than jump in mid-air. It's very difficult to control and really hard to master. So a large part of this game is really just trying to get to a certain platform by portal jumping, with not much else going on.

I got this game for about $0.51 when it was on sale so I can't really complain too much, but for me this game is definitely not worth the $2 price tag.
