29935396.review:
I love a good puzzle-platform game and OTS is more than just that. Aside from teleport gun puzzles and platforming navigation throughout the game, you have a story line that ends with a punch-line (a duh moment). The game is highly entertaining to play and I enjoyed playing it the first walkthrough blind. Now that I have completed the game once, the achievements keep the game with a tiny level of replay value. Some are definitely harder to complete because of how the game is designed (backtracking/forgetting something). However, you get to have 3 save-slots so you can take your time and have different slots saved to perform different acheivement as you complete one before the other. Or you can just use the guides present in the community if you aren't into hardcore solve everything by yourself :D.

The game design is mostly simplistic and the different mechanics makes the game enjoyable to master as you progress through the game. You will definitely see the game differently if you've played it once and play it again. The graphics aren't what you call the best, but this is a 2D game. For a 2D game with these graphics, it's definitely on the higher-end imo. The gauss gun is there as a way to kill your enemies, but I definitely enjoyed the game more via the teleport gun because of the puzzles.

Overall, highly recommend this game to people that likes a puzzle-platform game that has a little more and can be played relatively quickly. I finished it in a little over 1 hr by playing leisurely. One of the achievement is to finish the game in 20 mins so this would definitely be a short game. 8.5/10!

29931615.review:
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/263980/] UN BUEN JUEGO QUE DEBES TENER [/url]

[i] Out There Somewhere [/i] como podemos ver, es un juego de plataformas que se enfoca en la teletransportacion, ofreciendo una serie de desafios bastante variados gracias a diferentes mecanicas que plantea, sobre todo los laseres de colores. En el juego si nos causan daño nos eliminan automaticamente y regresaremos al ultimo checkpoint.

[h1] Jugabilidad [/h1]
En mi caso lo jugue con un control de xbox y no puedo quejarme de nada, es excelente en ese sentido. No creo que usando el teclado haya diferencia. Asi que le doy un [u] 10 [/u] en ese aspecto

[h1] Mecanica de juego [/h1]
Como ya dije, se basa en la teletransportacion pero existen elementos en el escenario que complementan muy bien esto. Por ejemplo los lasers. El rojo no te permite teletransportarte, el azul si y el verte redirecciona tu rayo. Hay otras cosas pero eso mejor deberian experimentarlo personalmente ustedes. Asi que le doy un [u] 8 [/u] en este aspecto. Solo por el hecho de que es algo repetitivo y limitado.

[h1] Enemigos [/h1]
Los enemigos no son realmente tal cosa, desde mi punto de vista son mas otro elemento del escenario que si tocamos nos matan, algo asi como en los primeros mario bros. Lo mas cercano a un enemigo es una especia de murcielago que nos "sigue" pues casi siempre lo puedes esquivar facilmente. En este aspecto le doy un [u] 8 [/u]. Porque la IA no es un desafio pero cumple con su papel.

[h1] Historia [/h1]
La historia es algo basica pero disfrutable, no es compleja ni nada por el estilo. La describiria como formulaica, pero aun asi no se puede pedir mas por el estilo de juego asi que le doy un [u] 9 [/u].

[h1] Jefe Final [/h1]
[b] SPOILER [/b]

[spoiler] La batalla final es lo unico que no me gusto del juego, ya que de todas las mecanicas del juego, no utilizamos nada realmente. Es bastante pobre, lo unico que le agrega de novedad es cuando lo enfrentamos por segunda vez, y aun asi no presenta algo muy desafiante ademas de que es horriblemente corta. Aqui si le doy un [u] 5 [/u]. Porque no supieron sacar bien el potencial de todo lo que practicamos a lo largo del juego. para poder utilizarlo al final. [/spoiler]

[h1] Dicho todo lo anterior en general le doy un: [b][u]8[/u][/b] [/h1]

29817513.review: Out There Somewhere isn't a normal game, though: it's a platformer with a devious twist and a truly shocking difficulty curve. It's a platformer with a very late level, for example, that contains absolutely no platforms at all - just empty space and a doorway right near the ceiling. With this weird, atmospheric brainteasing oddity, the Brazilian micro-team Studio MiniBoss has put itself firmly on the indie game map. This is challenging stuff, but it's wonderfully creative with it, and I'm not sure I can recommend it enough.

29322850.review:
TL;DR This game is gold. Cheap gold, at that.

It’s a delightfully simple platformer that is much more of a “puzzle platformer,” if such a thing exists. The game mechanics are very simple and the controls are nicely tight.

The game mechanics involve avoiding various obstacles (the usual, lava, monsters, projectiles, although there are very little and it’s more trying to get around the level than dodge), and using your Teleport Gun which may or may not have been stolen directly out of Portal or something – I don’t know, as I haven’t played Portal. Whatever its origins, it’s quite an interesting mechanic as it conserves speed, meaning that if you have enough space (and are required to do this twice) you can climb up an entire screen.

The game has nicely low quantities of threats, focusing far more on actually getting to the next stage – especially as you only get something that can actually kill mobs mid-game (and if you head back to that screen, they respawn) You can afford to misjudge a jump or a teleport and nothing bad will happen, really – there’s checkpoints on most levels, and when there isn’t it’s usually because there was a checkpoint at the end of the previous one (“level” is an odd word to use, “screens” is much better).

Surprisingly, the game does not through absurdly large quantities of obscure once-use-only bricks at you that you see in two levels and then never again. The only example is the “Mirror” block, which reflects your teleport bullet horizontally; this appears in three levels and then is completely forgotten about; rather amusingly it’s possible to complete those three levels without using the mirrors anyway.

There’s two other unwritten rules of platformers this game breaks:
- The final boss has only two, not three phases (three is a magical number in video games)
- There is no screen whereby “Jump over the lava pits” / “Jump repeatedly onto platforms”


Speaking of bonus sections, despite being a rather memorable platformer whereby the main challenge is routing, meaning it’s much easier the second time, the game has surprisingly large replay value (for a simple platformer). It took me an hour and a bit to beat the game the first time, but I continued to complete it about five more times (and a good deal of that was in Offline Mode, so that’s why the playtime is so low). The game has this high replay value thanks to a large quantity of bonus sections (on your first playthrough you probably won’t go through about 1/3 of all the screens), which are accessible from the get-go but you haven’t learned the ins and outs of the teleport gun yet. And because the game knows that it’s going to be easy and a bit of a slog, it makes the game easier for you – these bonus sections contain three types of useful stuff. It’s also got interesting, not grinding, achievements which is always something worth noting – and also ones that you probably won’t unlock by accident whilst merely idling through. Most achievements are either “Grind grind grind” (e.g. AOE2’s “Win as Civ X 1000 times for EVERY SINGLE CIVILIZATION (about twenty of them) or “Play the game” (e.g. Terraria’s “Chop a tree! Make an anvil! Find a chest!), and it’s nice to see some achievements that you not so much have to actively think about getting – it’s more they don’t happen by accident. If you explore lots you’re bound to get a good deal of them.

This is also the only game whereby I have been able to stunlock the boss thanks to some exploits in the boss AI, as well as fire more bullets than the final boss does – however, this requires intensive exploration. When you fight the first phase of the boss, despite only having one life his attacks are easy to dodge when you know how (although I spent a solid seven minutes dying repeatedly until learning how to dodge) – when you have four and a machine gun it does become a bit of a joke. Still, it is a lighthearted final boss in line with the light difficulty of the rest of the platformer. It’s more puzzle than run ‘n’ gun, although not much “running” happens anyway.

The difficulty curve is very nice, probably slightly too slow – but the game is very lighthearted and not meant to be insanely difficult. The game gives you a decently large quantity of hints in the game on tips of your teleport gun, but not enough to be an insta-win and also low enough to keep me occupied on a single screen for about ten minutes before finally working out what to do.


Progression is extremely linear with the exception of about three cases, which is a bit odd as this game would have lent itself to a multi-route system extremely well. 


The soundtrack is merely “good.” What stops it from being “excellent” is the fact that the composer had so many nice melodies, nicely hummable in their own right, and just lumped them all on top of one another in certain sections. To call those parts of the music “busy” is an understatement, but one track – Surface – doesn’t do that nearly as much and is much nicer to listen to. If the soundtrack was a little more… heh, a little more ‘empty’ in places (only in places) it would be “excellent.”

Oh, and the game has precious little plot, enough to give you information on what’s going on but nothing particularly huge – but unlike some platformers, it doesn’t throw you into wacko things that should never have existed (why are there so many homing rockets and landmines in some icy mountains? Who put these all there and why is there a convenient route through them instead of an impassable barrier – that’s Airscape for you). So that’s nice.

And to top it all off, I checked the Store Page’s price.
$1.09 NZD – and that wasn’t on sale. It [i]wasn’t[/i] on sale. Amazing.

[i]Out there somewhere[/i] is a very cheap platformer game, and in this case you get nothing more than what you paid for. A bland, uninspired jumpfest. The game consists of you having to perform tricky jump after tricky jump until the end credits roll. 

[i]Out there somewhere[/i] claims to be "Inspired by Cave Story, Super Metroid, and Portal," I don't see it - at all. I'd call it a lie in an attempt to boost sales, but there's nothing wrong with saying what inspired you, I guess. A satanic death metal band could claim the inspiration for their latest album was the Beatles' white album, even though you'd never actually [b]hear[/b] that influence in any of their music.

Apparently, if you're good at this sort of game, you'll finish [i]Out there somewhere[/i] in less than an hour and are entitled to some bragging, for example in the form of the Steam Achievement for finishing the game. If you're not particularly good at this sort of game, you'll notice they managed to make 'Out there somewhere' very challenging (difficult) but forgot to add any fun or wonder to the gameplay, which would motivate to try and finish it anyway.

All in all, [i]Out there somewhere[/i]  is a below average platformer that's only for the die-hard platformer gamer who's looking for a quick but extremely difficult fix.

29049914.review: Fantastic, but short, puzzle-platforming game. The primary mechanic is your telegun, whose bullets don't hurt enemies but do instantly teleport you to whatever surface they hit. The devs manage to stretch this mechanic quite a bit and create a few very tricky rooms. Art is just pixel art, but it's very good pixel art, and the music is stellar; overall, the alien atmosphere feels very well-fleshed-out. My main complaint is that this is not a Metroidvania game, as the inspirations it lists on the store page would imply; there are a couple heart containers and ship upgrades, but the latter are pretty useless and the game itself is basically linear. Rather than drawing in fans of Super Metroid or Cave Story, I think people who enjoyed VVVVVV would be the most likely to have fun with Out There Somewhere. Again, it's short: my first run through the game took about 50 minutes. Though, it's a good bit longer if you're a completionist, since getting all the achievements was about 3 hours total without a guide. Plus, if you're of the speedrunning type, then the telejump mechanic offers a lot of potential there. The game's only $2 at full price and gets even cheaper in sales and with various bundles, so if you happen to see it it's definitely worth picking up.

28763597.review: Simple and short but extremely fun and creative little platform/puzzle game. This game was made by a very small team, and it's a really impressive achivement! You've got an extremely limited move set - you can jump around, you can fire a teleport beam, and you eventually get a blaster - but you'll use that limited move set in a wide variety of funny, clever, unexpected ways. There were so many times where I thought, "Oh, this trick move won't work", and then it did! So then what if I jump off here and then shoot my beam there, but before I land, I jump and then...oh, that worked too! The game is just full of surprises like that and all these puzzles that test your creativity, logic, and ability to exploit the mechanics. I also really like the pixel graphics - the art style is charming and memorable. I don't actually have any real critiques here! It's a short game, but it never outstays its welcome. There are even a decent amount of secrets and it'll take you a while to really collect everything. On top of all of these strengths, Out There Somewhere is really cheap - it even often goes on sale for something like 25 cents. You can't beat that! You can wait for one of those super cheap sales if you like, but this is an awesome little game at any price. In fact, this is probably one of the best deals on Steam, bar none.

28650535.review:
Out There Somewhere is a platformer game with a unique mechanic in the form of the teleport gun. Using this gun you fire a shot that when it hits a wall, will teleport you there, as is its name. Sounds simple, yes? But not so, no. The things that you can do with it are many, which you will find as you figure it out to get past levels. Never did it feel like the game was impossible, though frustrating certainly (lot of it self inflicted). The experience was quite good.

Pros: Unique mechanic, good art style, acceptable level of difficulty.

Cons: Lack of any real story beyond good guy chasing bad guy (see those guys on the cover art? you'll only ever see each one once except the main character and throwaway alien NPC's), my own gripe on the short delay on firing your teleport gun after using the gauss gun (your basic pew pew, nothing fancy), and that you're given a health bar of sorts despite it being redundant as you'll always die in one hit (exclusion being the bullet hell shooters, but those are literally a game apart from each other)

Verdict, play it. I'd say get it on sale, but if you're a fan of platformers than it's not a bad purchase full price.

28504900.review:
This is a great little game! Very short (I beat it in under 1 hour), but it was very enjoyable, while it lasted.

The visuals are nice, and so is the music. Nothing new in these 2 aspects, but they're faithful to the games that inspired this game and they're well done!

The game has one main mechanic, and then some variations that support it. The mechanic is simply a teleport gun. You shoot a pellet that teleports you to it when it hits a wall. That's it. 
Despite its simplicity, though, it changes movement just enough to be "surprising", in some way, reaching escape velocity from "generic platformer".

The level design is pretty good, always pushing you to use what you've learned about the teleport movement, instead of presenting normal platforms. There are also details spread throughout the game for speedrunners, which gives it another layer for those interested.

The one complaint I have is that it is too easy, for the most part. There are hidden health-ups and armor for your ship, but these are mostly inconsequential to the game, so they're there for the extra challenge. Which is ok! The problem is that the game locks you out very often. 
You cross a certain section, and then you can't go back. This is a bit annoying, since the upgrades seen in one screen may require you to go around from another screen to get. So you may keep pushing forward, looking for the path, and then realize you can't go back... oops.

Since the game is 1 hour long, this is not really a problem? But it's not optimal either, I would have prefered the other way.


Anyway. Not much more to be said. It's not groundbreaking, but it's a very enjoyable title if you're looking for something quick, but still good!

28457135.review:
It's about time I gave this a review, considering how strongly I feel abou it. Just finished another playthrough of it, and I have to say that this game had me on a leash for my entire playtime. It could practically toy with my emotions at will, and has. And ninety percent of that comes from the writing, which is humorous, but still touching. 
While I can't give too much away (you might be tired of hearing that, sorry), I can say the characters are memorable and well-rounded, the world building is fantastic, and the twists always had me. That's probably the number one thing that will stand out about this game; the major twists (which you certainly won't find within one playthrough).
There are flaws, and I should be outright about them. While the character design is, as I said, memorable, and the color scheme really pops, the pixel art itself is not the best. It's not always easy to interpret what you are looking at. And while the writing is still great, sometimes it gets into weirder territory, which annoyed me a little. It also does go a little too far with what it's trying to do sometimes.
The gameplay also has a unique twist on the RPG formula as well. Rather than leaving things to chance, Undertale judges your hits on a simple quick time event, and allows you to simply avoid enemy attacks. On top of that, you also have the option to spare an enemy, if you can figure out how to calm them down. This means that every enemy encounter is a moral choice, and while that's usually a bad thing, here it completely works, due to, again, the writing. I found myself not wanting to kill these monsters after a short while, even though it raises your LV thus giving you more health. Still, sparing monsters becomes more and more difficult as time goes on, as does avoiding taking damage. It does get tiring sometimes, but the formula is shaken up from time to time.
Overall, it had me absorbed from beginning to end, and I highly recommend it for the story alone, on top of the gameplay that manages to mesh with the plot so well.

Gameplay seemlessly joins skills and wits, thanks to one simple, but innovative machanics.This blends nicely to the world and the story, and turns the game into an unpretentious and surprisingly coherent adventure.

28221524.review:
Definitely a good value for its price, especially if you get it on sale (which seems to happen frequently). Though definitely a short game, it ought to entertain for The few hours that you spend with it. The puzzles are nowhere near rage-inducingly difficult but very satisfying to solve, as they should be. The controls are responsive and reliable, so you'll suffer few to no cheap deaths. As a puzzle platformer, Out There Somewhere provides a strong enough gameplay framework that I would gladly play a much longer game in its style.

A ver... Este es mi primer análisis que hago así que no se que hacer.
por eso os voy a contar mi opinion sobre la pirateria.
basicamente yo cada juego que sale, que capta mi atención me lo descargo pirata. porque? 
no es solo porque asi lo tengo gratis no no, esque asi si el juego que me he descargado es una mierda me alegro de no haberlo comprado y haberle dado mi dinero a ese hijo de puta que me ha vendido un juego que no me gusta, en cambio si el juego en sus creditos finales o por el principio me convence ahi si es cuando grito "papa dame 5€ pa' comprarme lo juego" y abro Steam y me lo compro porque quiero que mi dinero vaya a esa persona que me ha hecho pasar un buen rato jugando. 
Y este juego pasa lo mismo solo que no lo piratee, me lo compre porque vi un video de un youtuber que lo analizó y como en verano estaba a 0.34€ el juego y la banda sonora pues venga vamos a probar y ahora es cunado os digo que si hubiera pirateado el juego, desde el minuto 2 le habria dado al Alt+F4 lo hubiera desinstalado y le habria pedido los 5€ a mi padre porque se los merece.
El juego no se porque me dice que solo he jugado 0.5h ya que mi primera partida me duro como 2h (aunque los logros que conseguí si que se grabaron 😆) 
Este juego es una pasada osea...
porque? 
Porque por lo corto que es, por lo corto que te dicen que es, me ha gustado MUCHÍSIMO más que muchos juegos AAA que he jugado. 
Este juego es como te dicen en la página de compra, se inspiraron en portal y en otro que no me acuerdo muy bien. 
Eres un tío que persigue a un malo maloso y tanto el como tu caeis en el mismo planeta. Tu mision es con una pistola que donde caiga la "bala" eres teletransportado hasta donde este colisiona para derrotar al malo maloso.
Durante la partida puedes coger módulos para mejorar tu nave pero no es obligatorio (aunque lo mejor es que cojas los más que puedas).
Me encantan los juegos de puzzles y tengo que reconocer que estos no necesitas una ingeniería espacial para resolverlos pero es cierto que cuando me ponen un puzzle me quedo en plan...
Venga ahora que hacemos.
Cosas malas que le puedo sacar...
Que es corto? Pero si es genial por el hecho de que lo corto que es lo que te puede ofrecer hostia!.
Tiene unos graficos pixelados MARAVILLOSOS, una banda sonora que te cagas, es de esas que son pegadizas y estas feliz de que se te qeude en la cabeza porque molan.
por la coña diria lo de 10/10 IGN solo que a la prensa este tipo de juegos no interesa porque para que inflar la nota con un "simple" juego de 1h no merece la pena por juegos de mierda que tienen un 9.5/10 pues han sido un tanto inflado.
esto me irritaria decir 10/10 IGN no no esto es 12/10 GIOVANNI (hola sou yo :3).
Y hasta aquí mi primera crítica para un juego, me habré dejado algo seguro pero con esto estoy contento :3
Edito: la única pega (sabia que me olvidaba de algo) es que no está en español, pero con un mínimo de inglés ya entiendes por donde tienes que ir y porqué.

26565131.review:
A nice little game that's easily worth the price of admission. Short and sweet, but doesn't fail to dissapoint you in the aspects of the game. 

The game itself is a fun game to play. The story isn't anything to rave about, but it really isn't meant to be a story driven game. After completion of the game, you won't really feel like you have been cheated out of a story because the value lies in the gameplay.

The formula of the gameplay is well done. Combine the likes of Portal and Cave Story into a unique game, and you have yourself a couple hours of shooting portals trying to go from Point A to Point B while trying to reach the goal. 

The enemies themselves aren't really challenge, and felt more like something to be aware of than enemies that you need to mindlessly kill. Killing an enemy was essentially removing the obstacle needed to advance because in all cases where the enemy wasn't blocking the way, the enemies could simply be portalled past. The bats got a tad annoying at times, liking to slowly home in on your character, but were a mere annoyance more than an actual threat due to you not being able to tank any hits.

The game was happy to provide you with lots of save points, mostly at the start of a room so that you didn't have to redo a previously completed puzzle in the case of death. On top of that, the save points themselves act as a respawn point, and with infinite lives, you were free to try to work out a solution for the puzzle without fear of getting a game over screen.

The beginning and end of the game consisted of pilotting your ship through space. I didn't truly enjoy it that much, as it's been done a million times over in countless games, but at least the beginning of the game immediately sent you to the platforming phase when you died. The end of the game had the final boss in two phases, one of which was in space. Neither of them were that hard, but the space phase, whilst a mere annoyance of having to reenter space after the fun platforming, felt needed due to the fact that the entire game revolves around you trying to fix your ship.

Overall though, the game is short, perhaps a little too short. As soon as the game really started going, and you were doing some intricate puzzles, the game immediately has you enter the final bosses tower and the game simply ends there. In my own personal opinion, the game ended almost a little bit too soon after reaching it's potential. 


Verdict:

Pro's:
+ Fun gameplay with a good scaling difficulty
+ Good fitting soundtrack to accompany the game
+ Puzzles that were fun, and with the nonexistant penalty of death, you felt no pressure to rush yourself.
+ Graphics are nice for a game that uses pixel sprites.

Con's:
- Game is a little short, and feels like the game could have gone on a little bit longer once it has shown you its full potential.
- Slightly tedious and annoying space sequences at the beginning and end of the game.

Overall:
Highly reccomended. The downsides are easily overweighed by the upsides when also taking into account the price of admission. Would easily buy a fleshed out sequel, possibly even shell out more than the nickles and dimes spent on this one if it was longer and improved upon the successful formula of the first.

Out There Somewhere. Una Joya.

Al inicio estaba con duda sobre este juego, dado que el precio al que lo consegui fue muy bajo. Pero una vez entrado en este, uno puede apreciar que este juego es un pequeno tesoro.

En cuestion de jugabilidad, Out There Somewhere es simple: Analiza, Salta, Dispara, Avanza, Repite. Puede sonar repetitivo, pero los diferentes Rompecabezas que ofrece cada nivel hara que te quedes un momento pensando en la solucion, para despues salir adelante con esa magnifica sensacion de Eureka que viene al descubrir el truco del nivel.

En cuestion de Soundtrack: Me encanto, tuve la oportunidad de conseguir el juego con el Soundtrack, y cada vez que reproducia una cancion en mi reproductor, me recordaba a cada nivel y cada dificultad que pase. Incluso me hizo fruncir el seño al recordar todo el tiempo que pasé en un nivel, intentando resolver el rompecabezas.

Al juego no le veo nada malo. Tiene un valor de rejugabilidad en el cual puedes conseguir todos los coleccionables y secretos.

Un juego corto, y muy bueno.

It turns out all i had to do was git gud. Once i figured out how to double jump, the game was a breeze. I even did a second, much quicker run of the game where i was able to get nearly all cores and artifacts, upgrade the ship, and defeat the bad guy, in 40 minutes or less.

So... the game is actually pretty decent after all: cute graphics and music, and fairly interesting puzzles and secrets.

By the way, the secret to double jumping is that the character must touch the floor and jump right before the teleportation. So, just time the jump to land before the pellet hits the wall, keep your eyes on it, and jump right before it hits.

25773229.review:
[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
Out There Somewhere is a 2d puzzle platformer with a hint of old arcade-space-shooting at the start and end, making the nice sandwich, which is "Out There Somewhere", developed by MiniBoss and released Mar 14, 2016.

[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b] You play as the Protagonist: Small-pixel-man-with-goldfish-bowl-on-head. Goldfish bowl head starts out by flying a ship trying to shoot down space-captain-who's-his-face. [i](Can you tell none of the names stuck with me?)[/i] While the story and plot are pretty forgettable the game controls aren't in the slightest.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=769464616

[b]Gameplay:[/b] The basic controls are straight forward, you move right and left, jump and fire a portal gun, later you unlock a regular gun you can use to kill the various hostile NPC's. The controls work, I have been guilty of mixing up my two fire keybindings, which has resulted in death-by-NPC-face-hugging, or teleportation-into-pits-of-death [i](For clearification sake, your teleportation gun fires THROUGH NPC's hostile and friendly.)[/i], the controls weren't so bad for me, but the game really seems like it was designed more so with a controller in mind.
But I'm getting ahead of myself, you start with just a Teleportation Gun, you fire a shot and when it connects with the wall, you teleport to the location of the laser/bullet. You actually have a few tricks you can pull off with the Teleportation gun early on, but don't learn about later in the game, so there is some skill that is developed with the Teleportation gun, rather then fire and teleport.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=769463749
So once you finish playing the game, and if you start a new game you realize there are many hidden spots in the game that you originally had no idea where there. So that hints at the amount of time it takes to finish the game: it's a pretty short game, think an hour or two on average [i](Naturally the time to beat the game after your first, will rapidly decrease unless you're trying to find new locations and secrets)[/i].

While I personally didn't find any of the puzzles too overwhelming, there's definitely plenty of difficulty to keep you mumbling obscenities under your breath as you get murdered again and again. While there's definitely more to the game, and plenty of content to keep you coming back, that's about all there is to say for the gameplay.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] As a whole, I enjoyed playing this game. This was one of the games I downloaded and played on my laptop while I was on a short little vacation away from my normal habitat. For using on lower powered computers I highly recommend this game, but when it comes to powered up computers that are normally playing MMORPG's or triple A titles... Out There Somewhere is still a pretty good diversion of a game. Pick it up on sale, play for a couple hours, go back to playing something else.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=769464966

1) Looks nice.

The negatives:
1) Damn it's short. It took about 1,5 hours of active playing.

3) The above also makes collecting the items (which are not mandatory, mind you) an annoying task.

In general, there's a polished feel to it, but I don't agree with all the design decisions. I'm also not sure if achievement hunting alone is enough to give that extra mileage I feel it needs. In any case it's really cheap, whether or not you feel you get your money's worth. Your mileage may vary.

Anyway, I'm going to keep my eye on the developers, as this shows they can produce high quality products.

25548968.review:
Out There Somewhere is a simple as well as simply priced game on Steam with a lots of detail added in such a short little space adventure.  While it is short in stature, it makes up for it with the quality put into the the low price, sprite-work, and the gameplay.  

The game itself costs two dollars on Steam, so it is very unlikely you will regret your purchase with all of the fibers of your wallet if you dislike it, unless of course those two dollars were needed to save you from dying of hunger. Of course, there is a chance one might receive a coupon for it upon crafting a badge or something, further decreasing the affordable price.  

The sprites give off a very solid Metroid reminiscence, which is fair because the game was reportedly inspired by Super Metroid.  Each of the environments are tailored almost exclusively with each screen that your character passes through.  They may have an underlying theme to it all, be it uncharted wasteland to menacing metal, but they all have something unique in level design incorporated within the game.  

The game is built around a teleportation mechanic.   A specially designed gun fires a blue bullet that, upon impact with any solid platform, teleports you to that specific location.  The gameplay revolves around you, and how you determine when to fire, not to mention time how long the bullet takes to reach your designated location.  

Of course, with all of those pluses, the game itself is rather short.  If you do not go out of your way to find any collectables, (and even if you do) the game boils down to a solid hour or two of total playtime.  Which is a shame, because the teleport gun mechanic is rather fun to play around with.  Another issue I have with the game is the way the levels are organized.  I feel as though game is very linear, each level designed to be a simple obstacle that prevents you from proceeding, so any unique level concepts are used once and left behind.  If one wanted to find the collectables aforementioned, they would have to backtrack through each of the levels that appeared to be designed in mind for separate challenges meant simply for providing something to hop through once and be done with, compared to games like the original Metroid or its remake, Zero Mission where there are several tunnels connected in a sense where you can be familiar with the layout and return without it feeling like you have to return through a single linear stretch.  

However, the game is a solid buy through and through.  If you feel like adventuring on an alien planet with a trusty teleportation machine, feel free to buy for a short yet sweet playthrough.

25117650.review:
Time of review: in 2 hours even, last room before the final boss; putting aside b/c bored and fuck that last puzzle.

TL;DR: twitch based puzzle plafomer, think VVVVVV with fancier graphics, no exploration aspect, and different mechanics.

1st off: unlike what the tags currently say; this is not in any way a metroidvania, metroidvanias are distinguished by a big focus on exploration, ferreting out secrets, etc. You don't do that in OTS, the game is very linear, backtracking is impossible, etc. Its similar to a metroidvania in the sense that there is just 1 big map... but thats about it.

What the game actually is at heart is a fairly difficult puzzle platformer, with a big focus on the platforming, you WILL need some good twitch skills to get thru some of the mid/late game rooms. Think VVVVVV except instead of swapping gravity you jump, shoot, & teleport, and you'll have a good idea.

Oh, and also there are space shooter sequences right at the beginning & end.

If you want a cheap, short, challenging game to kill a weekend afternoon, this is a good buy. Just be aware its only around 2 hours or so for a playthru, the platforming is very twitch, and it aint got any exploration.

25062555.review:
Out There Somewhere is a platformer/puzzle game with bullet hell stages, with mechanics that resemble Portal.
It's a very fun little game that, despite being very short (~2-3h of gameplay, maybe 4 if you want all achievements) is very entertaining and will keep you stuck to the computer until you beat it.

PROS:
[list]
[*] Beautiful pixel graphics
[*] Funny and simple storyline
[*] Very rewarding to figure out how to pass certain levels
[/list]

CONS:
[list]
[*] Short Game
[*] Storyline is not too deep, you won't get very attached to the characters
[*] Those who do not enjoy Bullet Hell (or are bad at it) will suffer at a couple points [spoiler]I died so many times at the final boss it gives me nightmares til today[/spoiler]
[/list]

24798270.review:
Out there somewhere is one of the hidden gems I have found while searching through Steam’s sales, and personally, I enjoyed playing through it.

	At first, OTS looks like one of the dime-a-thousand pixel-art 2-d platformers that make up quite a few of the indie games for sale on steam. When investigated further, it is revealed that the game is a bit above the rest.

	The main story of the game, is very simple, and is only there because it has to be in order for the game to make sense.

	Captain Yuri and crew fight off the evil alien, Grigori, and Yuri goes in alone to stop him, gets shot down, and lands on an alien planet. From there he must repair his ship, and find Grigori to defeat him.

	Bland and stereotypical as the story may be, the music is anything but, and ranges from chiptunes to electronic to orchestral. From the moment you launch the game, you are greeted by a dark track that gets you in the mood to play. While it may not be as memorable as Level one of Mario, or the Legend of Zelda theme, the music is still catchy, and because the soundtrack is $0.99 DLC, I listen to it in my spare time, in fact while writing this review I have actually been listening to the music to get in the spirit.

	The actual meat of this game centers around teleportation and momentum to solve puzzles. There are two side-scrolling shooter portions, but I’ll get to those later. You are given two guns at the start of the game, the teleportation gun, and the regular gun, with one heart, and one direction to go, right.  The main focus is of course the teleportation gun, which has momentum mechanics, basically, if you jump right before your shot hits a wall, you jump when you teleport there. There are also three beams and various blocks/mirrors that affect how your shot will land. Overall, the puzzle section is definitely solid. There are various power-ups, ship upgrades, and heart/health containers that you can find in capsules by exploring, but they are not necessary to beat the game.

	The first time I played through, it took me 2 ½ hours, without picking up any capsules. The game contains plenty for a short amount of time though; there are two ship battles with Grigori, where the parts you collected come into play, and one boss fight that uses the mechanics you’ve learned throughout the game, to go along with the puzzles and side-scrolling.

	For the price I bought it, I believe that the game is very good, with a few flaws here and there, and deserves a solid:
8/10

24609976.review:
[h1]The Short:[/h1]
-Short and sweet way to get your platforming fix.

[h1]The Thick[/h1]
[b]::[u]Pros[/u]::[/b]
[list]
[*]Interesting platforming dynamics made possible with unique teleport gun.
[*]Short enough to enjoy entire game in single play session.
[*]Priced fairly for what you get out of it (right now it is 1.99 USD and can be bought in indie bundle as well)
[*]Enjoyable throughout.
[/list]
[b]::[u]Cons[/u]::[/b]
[list]
[*]Really short. I continued my save file after the credits rolled in disbelief that the end came that quickly.
[*]NPCs are obnoxious. Most of them have nothing important to say and just get in the way of the gameplay flow.
[*]The platforming portion of the singular boss battle can be forced to only use his first two attacks simply by getting enough (like 3) attacks off on him during each cycle. This makes for an incredibly simple boss battle that felt more like just another platforming room rather than a boss.
[*]There is no real incentive to collect the optional ship parts. The shoot-em-up section of the boss battle is doable without upgrading the ship.
[*]Spoilers: [spoiler]Forced cliffhanger ending where the villian is still "Out there somewhere."[/spoiler]
[/list]

Random Thoughts:

I dunno... this game really makes me wonder if the developer didn't have a strict plan for what they wanted to make. The existance of relatively numerous NPCs suggest that there was going to be more of a purpose for them. Maybe for lore/world-building purposes? There also is really weird pacing in the game... though it is difficult to describe with the game being so short. I suspect (though I should note I have no idea if this is true) that this was planned to be a longer game. It certainly feels like there should be more (again, the price is very fair for what you get), and like many others seem to be saying, this entire game feels like it should be the tutorial/intro level of a larger game... and I think that was probably the plan initially...
Everything points to that theory:
[list]
[*]An abundance of NPCs most likely for world-building
[*]Stylized artwork for textbox profiles and the rare cutscene
[*]Progressive upgrade system for ship, which could have been spread out over the course of the game, as it felt completely unneccesary for the boss.
[*]Short to the point of it being unbelievable that the end falls where it does
[*]See final item on Cons.
[/list]

I do recommend this game because it's a great concept. I'm just disappointed that it wasn't explored further than it was. Don't get me wrong, I understand the limitations that a small team of developers can bring... I just think this could have been a great game. I'm disapointed not in the game, but in Miniboss for creating such a small game out of a concept with plentiful potential,

24473656.review:
TL;DR - I know my play time looks insane. You will assuredly not get 190 hours of this game, but you will get 2 of the most fun hours you've had gaming in a while. Buy now!

As my first foray into speedrunning, this game has given me several dozen hours of entertainment beyond what would be expected by reasonable gamers. But I am trying to be unbiased, and think of this game from a casual standpoint.

I still recommend it glowingly.

A quirky 2D platformer with a laser-sharp, utilitarian design approach, Out There Somewhere gives you a light dash of shooting combat, a gentle hint of exploration, and a core game built around puzzle-platforming with a 2D teleport gun. It is bookended by space shooter segments that some reviewers have taken issue with - I won't argue with them for finding these segments disjunct, but I still enjoy them anyway.

It is worth noting that the pace at which new mechanics are introduced is absolutely stellar - far better than many A-list titles. You get a sense for what each button does, a scenario or two that changes your approach, and then a wholly new element just as you are getting comfortable.

It seems like the biggest complaint from most reviewers is the game's short length. Most people should have an easy time earning the "Swift Success" achievement on their first play, it's true, but the collectibles should keep completionists occupied for another hour or so after - they even require a little meta-gaming! At a two dollar price point, this is plenty of game for your buck, and it's not often that this caliber of level design, soundtrack, and art style find their way into a two-dollar title.

SPOILERS AHEAD! In a sense this is actually 2 games, so I will talk about them separately. 

The shmup section was short but sweet, I am terrible at these kinds of games but I enjoyed it. My only issue is that your gun won't fire at full speed if you hold down the button, requiring you to mash for the most damage potential. I died as soon as the boss shot his laser, and though I'd need to restart until...

The puzzle-platforming section, which is the meat of the game. Crashing on the planet and needing to find ship parts (conveniently the same model as the shmup upgrades) reminded me of Knytt (in a good way), and so did the slower pace and early lack of combat. Puzzle progress felt steady and fun, though the "double shot" puzzle I managed to solve without learning the proper trick, stunting my progress in the next few rooms. I really enjoyed having a "teleport" gun instead of a "portal" gun, which felt very fresh as a mechanic. Combat was passable, with notable frustration trying to hit the flying bats, and not knowing how long the boss would take to defeat. The biggest issue I had was with NPC conversations, ending the conversation would not close the text box right away and another press would start it again; extremely frustrating.

Going back to shmup at the end was unexpected and exciting, and I didn't die to the laser! I was a bit sad that it ended, but that title call-out was a great wrap up to the story. The art and sound were excellent throughout, with a special mention to alien NPC designs.

OTS seems at first glance a very simple platform game. But as you move across the initial screens, you'll quickly realize that it revolves around solving interesting puzzles in order to progress. Armed only with a teleport gun, jumping, and the momentum generated by that same vertical impulse, you'll have to creatively navigate many kinds of static and moving obstacles. Requires creativity and good timing.

The story is basic to the point of being overlooked, just focus on the gameplay. It's light, and good for passing some time.

Positively surprised, more fun than it initially appears.

This game makes much of being inspired by Portal. But they missed one of the most important parts of Portal's design. This game deliberately punishes you for mistakes. Interesting game, interesting mechanics, wastes too much of my time.

Overall, this game is a fun experience! It's short, but at the price you can't really knock it for that. It's got a decent amount of replayability, especially if you want to find all the secrets and get all the achievments. It took me around 5 hours to get all the achivements, but anyone playing this just to play it will probably find themselves done in around an hour. 

The biggest thing I have against the game is that at one point it just switches from a platformer to a shmup, which wasn't a fun time for me, especially since it was a rather hard area. It's only one area, but in a game this small, that can be a huge downturn for me.

24103728.review:
Out There Somewhere is a 2D Adventure, Puzzle platformer developed and published by MiniBoss.
The beginning starts like a retro space game and after that your plane crashes on planet Unknown and take on the journey to repair your plane. In every stage of the game there are puzzles to be solved.
I bought it an year ago for about 0.15€ & since then you needed about 40-50 minutes to get the trading cards, I played, got them and uninstalled. But lately I've been struggling to find a good game that I haven't played (a lot) & this was one of the cheap games that was actually very good, so I gave it a try. After I completed the game, I can say that I am impressed from it.

Pros:
Retro graphics
Puzzles (every puzzle is different from the other)
Teleport gun mechanic
Good soundtrack
Cheap

Cons:
Very short (about an hour average time)
Combat (It's quite meh imo)

TL; DR
Fan of retro, 2D, puzzle games? Then this game is for you and even in full price, the game is worth it!

23780418.review:
out there somewhere es un juego de puzzles combinado con un portal, pero a su manera (ya voy a eso) cullo unico pecado es no durar mas de 2 horas si no te quedas atascado en ningun puzzle y no ves guias, por que de verdad vale la pena no ver guias, el ultimo puzzle me parecia una broma, pero no, y cuando descubri la manera en la que habia que pasarlo, quede con la boca abierta, pero ya basta de spoilers, pues si quieres infomarte mas sobre este juego y por que a mi parecer es una joya, pues preparate para leer pues el analisis super detallado de thenrgdrink (o una bebeida energetica que no tiene nada mas que hacer en la vida :v) comienza... AHORA!

[h1] gameplay [/h1] el aspecto mas llamativo de este juego y el que me insito a comprarlo es definitivamente el gameplay, pues tiene mecanicas parecidas a portal pero al mismo tiempo no, empiezas con el arma de portales, la cual tiene municion infinita y te teletransportara al lugar en donde el disparo impacte, pero donde esta el toque portal aqui ademas de los portales? pues en el momentum, ya que el movimiento se concerva entre portales (como dice GlAdOs en el primer juego de hecho) con esto me refiero a quesi disparas y cuando la bala impacte, si saltas el salto se mantiene en la teletransportacion, pudiendo asi llegar a zonas mas altas y dandole el reto al juego ya que a veces la cosa se complica mucho

[h1] soundtrack [/h1] el soundtrack de este juego es bastante bueno, cada zona tiene diferente tema y todos son buenisimos, el tema del jefe final se me quedo pegada, y a veces me quedaba en el final de una zona para escuchar la melodia una y otra vez, este hecho me demostro que estaba profundamente enamorado de la banda sonora de este juego, y eso esta muy bien, ya que los que me conocen bien saben que adoro los juegos con exelentes temas

[h1] historia [/h1] sobre la historia, no hay mucho que decir, digamos que junto a los graficos es el aspecto mas simple del juego (con eso no estoy diciendo que no me hallan gustado los graficos, al contrario, se podria decir que soy amante de los pixel graphics) eres el capitan yuri, y estas encargado de liderar una nave espacial para detener a un conquistador llamado grigori, cullo plan es conquistar mundos porque quien sabe que, en su busqueda, tu nave es atacada por grigori y te ves forzado a despliegar una nave de combate para hacerle frente, por desgracia, tu nave es dañada y quedas varado en un planeta que esta en proceso de conquista por grigori, y ahi empieza el juego... si ya se no es la mejor historia ni el mejor argumento que se halla visto pero cumple con su objetivo, hay que reconocerlo

[h1] npc's [/h1] la mayoria de los npc's de este juego no sirven, casi ninguno suelta o revela detalles de la historia para expander un poco mas el juego, y a pesar de que algunos si revelan detalles sobre la historia del juego, estos se pueden contar con los dedos de las manos, se podria haber jugado mucho mas con este ambito, ya que en lo personal, si los npc's soltaran datos curiosos sobre la historia de... yo que se, su mundo quizas pero cada uno cuente un trozo en desorden, eso me habria inspirado a rejugar el juego e incluso a crear una teoria sobre el mismo, pero no

[h1] conclucion [/h1] out there somewhere me duro solo dos horas, pero fueron 2 horas bien gastadas, y si bien es cierto que hay aspectos con los que se podria haber jugado un poco mas, nadie puede quitarle el hecho de ser entretenido y por que no, una buena experiencia que hizo que el dinero que gaste por el valiera la pena

[h1] nota final [/h1] le doy a out there somewhere un 7/10, no esta mal, es un buen juego, algo corto pero que dura lo suficiente como para mantenerte ocupado por el tiempo que te dure, no solo esta barato, si no que tambien esta de oferta... que estas esperando, ve y compralo, quierelo, amalo, dale de comer, y que no se te pierda :v

I have to say, this may verry well be the best $.49 I have ever spent

Pros
-Amazing teleport mechanic
-Good difficulty curve
-Great Music
-Treeman
-Overall gameplay is great


Cons
-It's short
-Bats
-somewhat annoying combat system

Bartle Taxonomy
Killers: Not the best game for these guys. You only get one gun, and it's not that powerfull. Not the best game for this type of player.

Achievers: Many achivements and ingame collectables to get. A great game for this type of player.

Socialisers: There is some interaction with aliens, but not a whole lot. Most aliens only have one line. There won't be much of any replay value for this type of player, but for the first time through it will be decent.

Explorers: Explorers should have a great time with this game. When playing through it, I often saw places I couldn't reach from my current position and thought "How can I get over there?" There are many hidden places to find. This type of player will have a great time with this game.

Score:
7/10
Make the combat less annoying, have more interaction with aliens, and make the game a bit longer. These are the only complaints I have about this game. However, for it's price, I highly recomend this game.

23594084.review:
Out There Somewhere is a retro-looking puzzlegame in which you navigate a 2D environment by the use of a gun that teleports the player around.

The game binds together puzzlesolving aspects that are mostly based on thinking and reflexes. 
Despite a mediocre plot, the gameplay itself was enough to make me play it through. The music was very catchy and I was glad to find that the soundtrack was included when my friend bought me this game. 

Pros:
- Good puzzles
- Originality
- Music
- Graphics

Cons:
- Short
- The story could've been developed more
- Not much replay-value

So is this game worth getting?
Yes. Despite the length of the game (1-2 hours, give or take) I find that you get quite a lot of enjoyment from it while it lasts. 
If you like the retro-style and enjoy puzzlegames, I'd recommend picking it up. Especially during sales, this game is an absolute bargain.

23592697.review:
[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title:[/b]  Out There Somewhere
[b]Developer:[/b]  MiniBoss
[b]Publisher:[/b]  EQ-Games, MiniBoss
[b]Genre:[/b]  Classic style platformer

[h1]General Impression[/h1]
Out There Somewhere is a 2D platformer that emulates the classic side-scrolling action of older titles while offering a breath of fresh air in the almost entire absence of platforming sections.  The story is all about a stranded astronaut trying to survive. Quite odd for a platformer is the lack of many enemies as well. You will mostly teleport here and there with ocassional text based dialogue pop-ups. This is definitely more an experience about exploration than combat and avoiding obstacles. Even if the game is rather short it felt a bit boring at times. It features simple graphics and sounds but for its price point and considering the inclusion of Cards and Achievements, the game is ultimately worth trying out.

[h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Plenty of collectibles.
+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
-  Unbalanced difficulty.
- Too short.

[b]Rating 6/10[/b]
 
[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews]Imperial Reviews[/url] and [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Cubbes]Cubbes[/url].[/quote]

23337856.review: Out There Somewhere is a wonderful game. It reminds me of Super Meatboy mixed with Cave Story and a little bit of the classic Metroid games. It has an amazing ost, the best 8 bit ost since Shovel Knight. The telaporting gun thing works really well and is used for some very challenging puzzles, that will most likely A: Make you relize the game is a little unforgiving to B: I want to ragequit, but I can't since the game is too addicting. I guess the only problem could be the 8 bit graphics since thats pretty overdone at this point by most old school 8 bit indie games like this trying to recreate what it was like to be a gamer in the 80s or 90s, but graphics are not everything if a game is fun. If theres any thing I'v learn from games like Earthbound, CaveStory, Undertale, and the old NES Mega Man games its that a game does not need to focus on the graphics if the gameplay is fun. Yes a game does need to have graphics that are appealing, not saying that any of those games are not appealing, its just that Out There Somewheres graphics should not be the foirst thing you at as critizism since that would make you miss out on a really fun not very well known indie game. It is currently 49 cents Steam so I recommed you check it out and buy it.

23295704.review:
[u][b][h1] Out There Somewhere [/h1][/b][/u]

It's a small game, but bunch of Fun you'll have. :)

[h1] GamePlay: [/h1]
The gameplay is as simple as the game is and yet sometimes challenging. At the beginning you'll have no weapon, which will change very soon till you get a teleport gun!

Teleporter gun: You can shoot with this gun and the time it hits an object you'll teleport to this point. Anyway this is just the half impressive part of it, because you can jump and while you're moving upward you can teleport yourself, but the physic of moving upward keeps. This is the part where it becomes a bit tricky to time you shoots.

Normal gun: Additional to the telegun you'll also receive a normal gun to shoot enemies. If you acquire the additional upgrade you'll shoot faster and deadlier which makes the run way easier.

This is the Charakter Gameplay. There are also objects in the world which tries to build up riddles for you. ;)
I love the idea. <3 (One point loss because it's really short 1h 20min. first run. :/ I wish I could be longer)
★ ★ ★ ★ ☆

[h1] Graphics: [/h1]
The graphics is a pixelstyle and not very impressive.^^ It looks very nice, but I just cannot give all points!
★ ★ ★ ★ ☆

[h1] Story: [/h1]
The Story is also well made. "Brevity is the soul of wit!" this is something fitting to its story. It's indeed not very long, probably because of the length of the game, but you don't forget storypart which confuse you in futher progress.

I really liked it. With some nice Cutscenes and dialogue.
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

[h1] Leveldesign: [/h1]
If you want all Achievements then you should know that you have to visit (nearly) every screen in this game. literally!
There are screens with no name and you'll have to see them to get the 107% Achievement. (I think it's pretty obvious why it's called 107%. :p)
The normal screens are well created to make puzzles, as I've said it befor. ↑ up there ↑
I don't see any reason to give less than the max. points.^^
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

[h1] Music: [/h1]
My favorite part of any game with good music recommendation. <3 Well, this game contains so many good soundtracks. I nearly love all of them and for a good reason. If you wanna take a look at the main Theme: [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9RNtTrgGNkg&list=PLoMc1zuUHF6Rk6Vd_Mxxhq1jXmwOTd9t-&index=2] Menu Theme [/url]
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

The summary is, I would buy it again and the most time it is in sale for less than 30c. xD Get it. It's worth to play!
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

22960506.review:
Very nice platformer with an interesting game mechanic.
You play as a captain of a space ship who ends up in a fight with a villain named Grigori (who is still out there somewhere btw)
It result in your ship crashing on some alien planet. Now you have to find your way through the planet to get a light orb to fix your spaceship (Every spaceship needs light orbs cause you know... reasons...) and optionally collecting "abandoned cores". You have a teleport gun which teleports you to where the shot lands... a cool game mechanic that is very well implemented.


Pros:
-Figuring out how to get to the end of every screen is a lot of fun.
-Timing and thought required make it enjoyable.
-Short but not too short.
-Tight controls.
-Good soundtrack.
-Good-looking pixel graphics.

Cons:
-Almost no story. (doesn't really matter for this kind of game ... use your Imagination)

Highly Recommended!

22847230.review:
I purchased this game during a recent sale and paid about 49 cents for it. The game is most definitely worth that price, but I cannot say it is worth the full 2 dollars.  

The Good:

1. I always have a soft spot for the pixelated, nostaligic graphics and sounds. 
2. The sound track is amazing and does tend to be stuck in ones head after you sit down the controller. 
3. The physics and animations were well done, basically perfect. 
4. I did like the merger of the side scrollinger shooter and the planetary exploration/platforming. I found them to be very   complimentary to one another in this game.
5.  Personally, I liked having to avoid the enemies, relying heavily on the telportation gun. I liked the puzzle aspect oft his game, though it was a bit easy. 

The bad:

1. The game was too short. My first play through, and not in any particular rush to beat the game, took 40 minutes.  this is taking into consideration the time I spent trying to get some of the extra items. 
2. The developers said this game was directly inspired by Cave Story and Super Metroid, but I fail to see much of those characteristics in this game. It is possible that I am not looking or thinking hard enough. I expected more weopons, different abilities that would allow you to progress, etc.  This game did not feel as atmospheric or epic as metroid and was not long enough to qualify for any kind of story, like Cave Story. 
3. The puzzle aspect of this game, while I love it, is wayyyyy too simple. Once you get the hang of the fact that the teleporation gun conserves momentum, you have beaten the game.  
4. Not a whole lot of variety. I disagree with the main character when he says that 3 types of beam obstacles are too many. They are not enough. 
5. One could argue that this is trying to turn the game into something its not, but: I wanted to see more than one planet. I wanted more intermmediate shooter levels and more planets to explore. I'm not suggesting a re-write, but the simple addition of more content that is already within the bounds of the game engine.  "I'm sorry, but Grigori is on another planet" would have been an accpetable transition between levels. 

Overall:

The game felt less than half completed, like a teaser trailer of itself. Imagine the first mario brothers game, on the NES, if the princess was really in the first castle. That is this game. 

I think this game could be great if it just expanded on the content a bit. I am not suggesting anything revolutionary. A few more obstacles and perhaps some variety to the planet (or add more than one planet).  Achievements do not do it for me and did not add to the game.  



For < 1 dollar, this game can be recommended. Not for the full price.

22738100.review:
Disappointing. 

Being on-boarded to a game with a spammy splash-screen is NOT a good indication of things to come. 

The actual mechanic was interesting and accessable, though I--a not-great player of games--finished in about an hour. I was narrating while playing, too, and demonstrating, so actual gameplay is probably closer to 45 minutes for a good player. 

I probably won't go back and 100% the achievements. It's just not worth it to me, so that is telling.

Is this game worth it on sale? Yes. Is this game worth it full price? Not for me, but probably for most people. Just bear in mind that you're paying for around an hour's worth of entertainment, and this is a one-shot deal as there is no procedural generation at work here.

It really hurts me to not recommend this game...

Because when you look at it, it is very pretty, the gameplay is smooth, and all the art design (atmosphere, sounds, story...) is very nice and thought.

But... it is much too short, and quite unsatisfying in terms of experience. It is definitely a flaw in games these years, although some others would argue it is a plus. Yet for me, such a small contribution in terms of entertainment and gaming is exactly like with toys and games... a diminished version, a raw skeleton without any flesh or organs.

In other words? The type of gamer I am can not feel fully satisfied with what feels like a demo, like a "short story" of a gameplay mechanic. Please realize I am not asking for a 100hours long rpg, but this "little gamish piece of art" would have been great if there was more substance to it, more body. 22621711.review: I got this for free through a giveaway please note. The game overall is pretty fun once you get a hang of the mechanics and such. The maps and graphics are designed well and the soundtrack is very nice. Before you get the physics down the game can be very boring and frusterating but once you get the hang of it, the gameplay is very rewarding. The game is pretty short, about 2-3 hours depending on how good you are at thhe game and how fast you get used to the game mechanics. Although if you are an achievement hunter there is a lot of bonus stuff to do and a lot of secret areas. The game sometimes lags which usually doesn't botch you up but beware and the response time is pretty mediocre. I think the one thing that got me the most was the final boss battle. Note that the first level is a bullet hell shoot em' up but is very short and very easy. The rest of the game is a platformer, with portal esque mechanics. The boss battle is split into two sections, the first being a platformer in which you jump around bullet and teleport past lasers while shooting with your pistol. The second stage puts you into a scenario very much like the first stage but 10 times harder. I really do not like it when games boss battle are completely different to the core gameplay and all your experiance and skills gained throughought the game is completely thrown out the window. Although scattered throughout the core game there is little secret bonus items you can pick up to boost your damage during this level, this does little to improve the anti-climatic boss battle in the end. Overall the game is pretty fun, can be kind of frusterating but is a steal for the price (especially if you get the game and soundtrack for free), I give it a 7/10.

This game is worth a lot more than it's price. Don't be fooled by the 199 cent price tag this game is good. Maybe even great. First off the soundtrack, is great, it's refreshing, catchy, and motavating in whatever area you are.
While the story is simple, this doesn't really make it worse, as the game is mostly reliant on it's puzzles for quality, and that's a good thing too, because the puzzle are pretty good also. They're all sentered around this portal gun that beams you to wherever the bullets hit. From there, new elements are added to modify gameplay slightly, but overall, the basics are the same. As far as difficulty, this game is a medium, although there will be certain rooms that are so strangely difficult and out of nowhere that you'll be tearing you hair out either trying to find the solution or trying to figure out how to put that solution into action, but most of the time it's a pretty smooth, slightly difficult challange.

Overall, I deffinetly recommend this game to anyone who likes platformers.

8/10.

Out There Somewhere is a game that feels like an homage to action platformer games like Cave Story and Metroid. It is on the short side of gameplay (about an hour or two), but I had fun the entire time and wanted more when it was over. It also has plenty of hard-to-reach areas with secrets that require some prior planning and well-timed actions once you have a feel for it on your first playthrough. It is a great game that brings back memories of early platformers with some new, creative elements of its own.
I'd highly recommend this game to anyone with a couple of hours to spare and a desire to play something that's just plain fun.

22202815.review:
This game is very interesting.
The story is about a space cop who is hunting a villain named Grigori. But after a fight with him, his space ship gets badly damaged and both land on a same planet. Main gameplay begins here and you have to find a light orb to fix your ship and defeat Grigori for good.
Gameplay is really nice. you have a teleport gun which is frequently used in the game and nearly all of the puzzles must be solved with it and a gauss gun to kill enemies. After progressing further in the game, you will encounter new enemies, three types of lightbeams, mirrors, breakable objects and moving platforms which add to the challenge.

PROS:
- Nice gameplay
- Great soundtrack
- Collectables affect how much hard the last fight will be
- Can 100% the game easily with a little skill and patience

CONS:
- Short (Can be completed in 14 mins to 75 mins on first playthrough)
- You HAVE to lose in the first encounter with Grigori and you can even lose at the beginning; but it's not clear. So you do your best to take him down and after a lot of minutes you find out it was a complete waste of time.
- Some rare achivement problems: One of the achievement did not unlock until I did it's required action for the third time.

VERDICT:
This game is really nice and definitely worths trying but it's short and after you unlock every achievement, you may not want to play it anymore.

22152691.review:
[h1]Wow! What a game![/h1]
 
I picked up the game on sale whilst drunk one night thinking that myself and a mate of mine would have a grand ole time with this cheeky, pixel art, puzzle-platformer game. And I was absolutely correct. We started playing with the idea of recording a lets play of the first 15 minutes and ended up shirking off our other recordings to keep playing for another hour and a half. 

Out There Somewhere is a perfect blend of challenging puzzles, a simple yet intriguing game mechanic, and a wonderful amount of tongue-in-cheek humor that all together keeps your mind actively engaged and your funny bone throughly tickled. 

MiniBoss did a wonderful job with Out There Somewhere, and we definitely hope they look to expand the game or create more games like it! Definitely pick up the game, it is absolutely worth the ridiculously low price tag. 

If you are interested in watching some gameplay here is the playthrough series we uploaded: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VELcRwPBRfA

22024742.review:
A really clever little game with interesting momentum based puzzles, amazing music, and fabulous pixel art.
The puzzles can sometimes be tough to pull off or just be downright confounding when you try to start working your way through it, but it's a good, refreshing kind of frustration (akin to Portal's frustration) that leaves you feeling like a genius and a platforming master by the time you get through it.
The spaceship portions are tough but simple bullet hells that killed me a LOT, but I just blame my poor dodging skills and it's by no fault of the game's mechanics or controls.
Although I was able to "finish" the game in around a total of 2-ish hours, I still have a looong way to go; especially if I hope to make a dent in the considerable list of achievements (and as if to add a cherry on top of this, the achievements also have more of that gorgeous pixel art! I love it so much).

And along with everything else, a big bonus was the price I paid for it - just $0.49!
So this game gets a really solid 8/10 from me.

22022209.review:
Ridiculously tight, well implemented 2D platformer that runs with the idea of a teleporter gun & mashes it with near perfect controls, puzzle design, and learning curve. You'll die, sure, but it's because you suck, rather than the game wanting to make you feel like you suck.

 What makes this is inspired is how well its gimmick, the teleporter gun, is implemented - you fire it, a bullet goes off traveling, and when that bullet hits something, you'll be instantly transported to that point - continuing your current momentum. That's what's key. 

You get eased into these simple 'jump up & shoot towards this platform you can't jump across to' puzzles & then suddenly you're jumping up, firing it off across to a wall, landing & jumping again in a different direction just as it hits, then repeating all that immediately in a different direction, but with none of the stress of a lot of these dumb modern-retro platformers. 
 
It rocks.

21949794.review:
Out There Somewhere (OTS) es un jueguecito muy entretenido y bien hecho, destinado a pasar un rato agradable recordando viejos juegos de pantallas como los Phantomas. En él, encarnamos a Yuri, un capitan espacial que lucha para derrocar a un malvado monarca espacial llamado Grigori. Para conseguirlo contamos unicamente con una pistola teletransportadora, una pistola laser y nuestra astucia.

El juego, con un bonito estilo pixel art retro y una buena banda sonora, nos pone un reto en cada pantalla, ya que debemos utilizar nuestras habilidades con ingenio para poder avanzar hasta la siguiente. Además, el juego cuenta con numerosos secretos que costará encontrar, y despues, obtener.

El juego comienza con un pequeño juego de naves a lo R-Type, donde lucharemos contra las fuerzas de Grigori. Finalmente nos encararemos con la nave nodriza del general, la cual es indestructible y nos tumbará irremisiblemente. Una vez superemos un aterrizaje forzoso, empezará la aventura plataformera de Yuri en un extraño y desconocido planeta en busca de un orbe energético para reparar la nave.
Ademas de llegar al final y enfrentarnos con Grigori, existen otros objetivos en el juego. Por el planeta se encuentran diseminados 11 celulas de energía, las cuales darán mas potencia a la nave una vez arreglada. Tambien existen varias reliquias que nos permitirán soportar mas de un golpe antes de morir.
El juego tiene vidas infinitas, y una vez se muera, Yuri restaurará su posición en el ultimo checkpoint que se haya tocado.

No es un juego excesivamente complejo, pero los puzzles estan bien diseñados y aprovechan mucho las habilidades de Yuri, el timing de las acciones y el entorno en si. Está muy bien que además, gracias a aprender a usar esas habilidades, podamos encontrar secretos, algunos bastante bien escondidos. Intentar hacer todos los logros le da algo de rejugabilidad, ya que si algo tiene de malo OTS es que es muy cortito.

Un juego bonito, divertido, entretenido y lleno de cosas que hacer. Dura poco, pero gracias a su bajo precio, es una buena compra. Le doy menos valoración de la que querría por su corta duración. Si fuera mas largo, sería un juego buenísimo.

Valoración: 7 / 10

Holy shit. When I initially saw this game on the store for 25 cents I wasn't sure if a game this cheap would be worth it. However upon downloading and booting up this game I was instantly met with waves of energy and joy. From when I hit "new game" I knew I was in for a ride, and what a ride that was. The music controlled the gameplay almost more than I did, forcing me in and out of situations that would seem impossible with the very sound of a note. The "portal gun", as one could call it, adds a new depth to the platforming which makes it fun, puzzling, and at some points infuriating. 
Out There Somewhere is like nothing I have played before, or as I should say, many things I have played before. The developers took Cave Story, Portal, Metroid, and VVVVVV and spat out one of the best indie games I have played in the past few years. I recommend this game to everyone who loves difficulty (while still beign fair), a simple yet entertaining narrative, and just some sweet bumpin' tunes.

21898467.review:
Out There Somewhere is a 2D platformer game which would have fit right in back on the NES. While the graphics are probably a bit better than what would have been around back then in some places, on the whole this is a pixel graphics game whose gameplay harkens back to a much simpler time.

You play Yuri, a space cop in hot pursuit of Grigori, some sort of bad guy. You start out trying to shoot down his ship, fail, and then have to travel across the planet to confront him and collect a light orb to repower your ship and beat him down in the end-game.

The game is very simple. It claims to be inspired by Cave Story, Super Metroid, and Portal, but honestly it is its own thing, and not very much like any of those games. It is very linear, there isn’t much of a plot, and it is very centered around its central game mechanic – a teleportation gun.

When Yuri fires his gun, he gets teleported to wherever it hits, with whatever momentum he presently has being preserved. He cannot teleport if he is already right next to the surface he would be teleporting to.

He can also jump.

These two mechanics make up pretty much all of the gameplay in the game. You do eventually get a gun you can kill monsters and destroy certain blocks with partway through the game, which opens up a few more puzzles, but most of the game is centered around platforming with the teleportation gun – including one room towards the end of the game with no platforms in it at all, which the player scales by shooting shots across the room, landing, then jumping just as the shot hits the far wall.

The game cost 50 cents on sale, and is extremely short – this is the sort of thing you can beat in a single sit down. I was pretty heavily achievement and secret hunting and beat the game in 89 minutes my first time through. All that’s left at that point is trying to figure out how to acquire the last few secrets, many of which are pretty devious (such as requiring you to go through about a third of the game without saving once so you can die and respawn at the very start with the block-destroying gun, in order to acquire one of the secrets).

Was it worth 50 cents and an hour and a half of my time? I can’t say I wasn’t entertained by it, but it wasn’t high-quality entertainment – the game is decent enough as what it is, but it is not exactly aiming for the stars. If you like 2D platformers with simple, straightforward mechanics, this is probably a decent choice for you; if you like nice graphics, complex gameplay, a sophisticated story, or anything else like that, you’ll probably be disappointed by this game.

21880291.review:
[h1]A brief fun and challenging 2D puzzle platformer[/h1]

I bought Out There Somewhere on a whim. It had good reviews on Steam, cost less than a dollar (was on sale for 49 cents) and was reported to be a short game. I didn’t have much to lose. Either I lose a few hours of my time or have a brief but enjoyable experience, fortunately it was the latter.

Out There Somewhere is advertised as “inspired by Cave Story, Super Metroid and Portal”. Great! I love all three of those games and I would consider Super Metroid to be my top games of all time. The bad news is that the game doesn’t really fit two of the games. It doesn’t have the multiple guns, boss battles and exploration elements in Cave Story and Super Metroid. The only game that is an apt description is Portal. Buyer be warned!

The primary mechanic of the game is the teleport gun similar to the portal gun in Portal. The only difference is that instead of summoning two portals, the teleport gun instantly teleports our hero when the projectile makes contact with a wall. The teleport gun makes way for some very interesting puzzles. One common scenario is where you would need to shoot at a wall and quickly jump to maintain momentum after you teleport.

Aside from the teleport gun, there is a blaster gun that you can use. Not much to say about it other than it takes a few shots to kill anything and doesn’t feel like it has a lot of impact to it.

There’s nothing to the story. In fact, I can sum it up in one sentence. Generic space hero gets his ship shot down, lands on a planet, explores the planet to find parts to repair his ship and once his ship is repaired he kills the bad guy.

I finished Out There Somewhere in an hour. I could have spent more time exploring and searching for hidden secrets but the game never compelled me to. After finding the parts necessary to get the ship up and running, I wanted to explore the world more. Oddly when I walked to the next screen I was abruptly placed back into the ship and fighting a boss.

Overall I had fun with Out There Somewhere. The game is appropriately paced and the puzzles had a nice even ramp in difficulty. The lack of content is concerning, but given the price there isn’t much to complain about. Out There Somewhere shines well especially when compared to other games of the same price.
