21877380.review:
Out There Somewhere claims to have been inspired by Cave Story and Super Metroid, but those games raise expectations in my mind that I feel the game did not meet. 
The game is far shorter than expected, my first playthrough lasting little more than an hour. It is also not nearly as varied as Cave Story and other Metroidvania-style games; you will spend the majority of the game with just your teleport gun and a normal gun. And while the puzzles involving the aforementioned teleport gun are definitely interesting, the claimed inspiritations led me to believe I would have a bigger arsenal at my disposal.
Another issue I have with the game is the use of bullet hell-like portions of the game. These sections feel very out of place in a game that is otherwise essentially a 2D version of Portal.

Out There Somewhere is a decent game, considering the price, but the tauted inspirations to me implied a set of standards that the game did not deliver. Like I said above, this is 2D Portal. If that is what you want, then this game will do. But if you're looking for something Metroidvania-esque, look elsewhere.

21860749.review:
Out There Somewhere is a puzzle game akin to Swapper, VVVVV, Portal, and any number of other games where there is a gimmick to move your playable character through puzzle environments.   Here you play as a tiny spaceman as he shoots rounds from his gun that instantly teleport him when the round hits a surface.  There are many different elements that flesh out gameplay like timed blocks, metal grates, beams that stop the round, beams that bend the round, beams that reflect the round, etc.   Your objective is nothing more than to reach the other side of the room so that you can journey on and collect space components to repair your spaceship. 

The graphics are pretty simple but are charming in their own right.  It's just some dark alien tileset and the enemies as well as the player are also a tile. Coming from how the game is played you don't need any more. 

The music is the only downside as nothing is catchy and may get on your nerves quick if you don't like 40 second BGMs from budget gameboy titles repeating over and over. 

All and all you can do no wrong getting this for under or near 1 USD.  Check this out, it's great fun and pretty addicting.

21844671.review:
This game is for those interested in speedrunning, looking at what your indie project could become, or a literal example of many game design teachings that stick out like a sore thumb. I would say that this game has its moments, but really, the game does nothing much to make itself have impact.

It's a metroidvania game that lacks bosses, multiple powerups, or smart puzzles that offer diversity over difficulty. There's collectables, but they require backtracking, knowledge of the whole game world, and rarely give you hints on how to reach them. A new game+ mode would've been super helpful, where it lets you explore the game world past the final boss.

If you're a sucker for gameplay that doesn't dip in quality, then sure, pick this game up for the dollar (or 25 cents) it's worth. You get it's full worth for what you pay. It's got cute character designs, neat gameplay designs, but there's not much more to the game than jumping around, some minor puzzles, and waiting for monster cycles. On the plus side, the game is short and straightforward to speedrun with the in-game timer mechanic.

As far as minimally priced games go, this is one of the better ones, but you could always save up your money for a fantastic 10 dollar game over the short-lived, lackluster experience of this one.

21586695.review:
Let me open by saying this game is cheap, but is it worth the price tag?

Yup.

I recently played(and reviewed) a similar puzzle platformer, VVVVV or some nonsense, which I didn't find was to my liking.  As such I had some apprehension about Out There Somewhere.  

I'll tell you that was some misplaced anxiety.  This game has a teleport mechnic that allows it to progress beyond simple muscle reflex puzzles and actually assess all the factors on a screen before proceeding with a solution.  After I completed the game, I felt satisfied.  I felt like I had accomplished some pretty interesting puzzle platforming, and I felt like I kind of wanted to play it through again.

All that being said, this game isn't very long.  I don't know how much time I spent playing it, currently, but I think it was about an hour(Edit: 54 mins...)  which was actually perfect since I was on a flight and after I finished we were close to landing.  I see myself playing this again on my return trip and probably enjoying it just as much.

One interesting thing I noticed in the options was the feature to turn on a timer, which seems an interesting little contraption to let you time your runs.  There's also a few areas I can think of where I may have been able to explore but they were early in the game before I really learned the capabilities of the teleporter gun.

That's another bit that's interesting.  They don't throw new items at you through the game to make places accessible, with the exception of a gun near the beginning.  Anything you are able to accomplish late game with the teleporter you can do at the start... provided you grasp the concept fast enough.  The gun you obtain later is really only to destroy blocks and enemies, but it seemed to me (nearly) every screen could potentially be accomplished without killing a single enemy.

The last bit I'll mention is that I played this game entirely on the Steam Controller, I've yet to find a platformer that doesn't work well with it, but I'll say playing a game on the plane was MUCH more comfortable with a controller in hand, rather than playing the part of a contortionist to access the keyboard wedged in front of me, though this is just commentary and doesn't affect my review of the game. 

Addition: OK, so since I was in an airplane and didn't pay for wifi, steam didn't register the time I'd played the game and wouldn't let me post a review with 0 minutes logged.  I started up a new game and can confirm in the 12 minutes of extra play time I found 3 screens I didn't even register existed on my first play through within the 'tutorial' section of the game.  So if you happen to be an achievement collector, or just like the game you can easily double that hour play time going through with a replay. 

Its worth the standard price(which is cheap as it is,) but if you find this game on sale, don't hesitate to nab it if you enjoy puzzle games or plaformers.  It's got some interesting mechanics.

I can't really recommend this game in good conscience.  It took me just over an hour to beat, and I was never challenged mentally or reflexively.  I tend to be a completionist, too.  I mean, it's not [i]bad[/i], it just wasn't very inspired.

The store page is perfectly happy to name drop both Cave Story and Super Metroid, despite those two games being nothing alike.  Out There Somewhere is way, way more heavily influenced by Cave Story than Super Metroid.  Expect an extremely linear adventure with a few relatively unimportant collectables lying one or two screens off the beaten path.

Almost nothing about this game is focused.  The NPCs you meet almost never have anything interesting to say, and the environments you wander through are inconsequential.  The core game mechanic is needlessly muddied when [spoiler]you get a gun that lets you kill enemies[/spoiler].  100%ing the game is impossible to do on your first playthrough.

21279051.review: Suprisingly good for a really cheap game

21231823.review:
This is a pleasant return to the past. Definitely thumbs up!

It contains pretty cool music, gameplay is not bad (if you change that strange control settings). It´s a pity that the game have such a short "story line". It would deserve to have a sequel or some kind of a DLC.

I would recommend it as a nice break from serious A titles.

21206750.review:
A decent little platformer. A bit short, but it's about right for the price. The controls work well, and the graphics and music are done nicely in its retro style. There's nothing mind-blowing here, but there's not any real fault that gets in the way of enjoying this game.

Probably worth a check if you're into platformers. If you're not, this is a safe skip.

69/100

21169582.review: It's $1 for a puzzle-platformer that'll probably last about an hour on your first go, has above-average pixel graphics and a pretty killer soundtrack, and a handful of pretty darn well-hidden trinkets. My only real objection is that said trinkets only serve to make the final boss even more of a cakewalk if you collect enough of them. Good deal!
